"23 September: From Friday, 25 September, bars and restaurants in the provinces of Vorarlberg, Tirol, and Salzburg have to close at 10 p.m."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201008004721/https://www.austria.info/en/service-and-facts/coronavirus-information

"Events  Events include, in particular, planned get-togethers and activities for entertainment, amusement, physical and mental training and edification. In any case, this includes cultural events, sporting events, weddings, film screenings, exhibitions, vernissages, congresses, training courses and further education.    For events without assigned and marked seats (e.g. standing events), the maximum number of people in closed rooms is currently 10 people. Funerals are excluded from this person restriction. There is a maximum of 500 people for funerals.  For events without assigned and marked seats (such as standing events) outdoors, a maximum number of 100 people currently applies.  For professional events with assigned and marked seats, the maximum number of people in closed rooms is 1500.  For professional events with assigned and marked seats, the maximum number of people in the open air is 3000.  The following applies:    The 1 meter minimum distance must be observed (people who live in the same household are exempt from this) and an MNS must also be worn in closed rooms (MNS also applies outdoors at markets and trade fairs)  The catering rules apply to catering establishments  At events with assigned and marked seats, the mouth and nose protection is not required when sitting if the 1 meter distance is maintained or another suitable protective device is available for spatial separation that guarantees the same level of protection  Outdoor events with over 100 people and indoor events with over 50 people must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a corresponding COVID-19 prevention concept  The event restrictions also apply to indoor social activities in groups  The people necessary for the implementation of the event are excluded from the maximum number of people (e.g. performers, orchestra)  In general, the limits do not apply to the professional area (including professionally practiced sports, music, etc.)"  https://web.archive.org/web/20201008005332/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/

On 14 October 2020, Finance Minister Gernot BlÃ¼mel held his budget speech in Parliament, presenting his draft budget for 2021.  -	EUR 29 billion for the labour market and employment. The labour market constitutes a central challenge and will therefore be provided with significant support. As a result, this coming year, significantly more money will flow into the labour market than in previous budget plans. In total, up to 2021 inclusive, over EUR 29 billion will be made available for the labour market and employment. -	At present, almost 704,000 people in Austria are unemployed or on short-time work. Because of this, more money than ever will be spent on employment and jobs. For coronavirus short-time work, aimed at providing all-round security for thousands of jobs, up to 2021 a sum of up to EUR 8.3 billion will be made available. Up to 2022, EUR 700 million will be provided for setting up a work foundation to support employment qualifications for up to 100,000 unemployed people, as well as the education bonus. Link: https://archive.vn/U6lLW

Austria orders the first local quarantine of its second COVID-19 wave. From October 17 until November 1, the Salzburg town of Kuchl in the Tennengau region will be put under 14-day mandatory quarantine. The driveways to the site are controlled by the police. Hotels and restaurants are closed, shops are allowed to keep open. Only key workers can commute in and out.   Links: https://archive.vn/TsVIf https://archive.vn/9QMOZ

On October 19, students in orange and red-colored districts in Tyrol must switch to âdistance learning,â or online instruction. Both parents and students are criticizing this order. Link: https://archive.vn/zpRsC
On October 19, it was reported that a federal curfew has not been decided.  Link: https://archive.vn/zpRsC

In Hietzing, Viennaâs 13th district, a big and growing coronavirus cluster around schools has been identified. Out of 333 new cases in Vienna today, 40 can be traced to the boarding school at the Himmelhof. Teaching is suspended for today. The Diefenbach Gymnasium (high school) â of which some students live at the Himmelhof â is also affected. At the moment, there are 350 active cases of coronavirus at Viennese schools and 54 at Viennese kindergartens.  Link: https://archive.vn/zpRsC

From October 20, guests in Upper Austrian restaurants and bars have to leave their contact details. In Vienna, such regulation has already been in force for several weeks. Link: https://archive.vn/zpRsC

Health Minister Rudolf Anschober announced that select physicians and dermatologists will offer a new fast antigen test for the coronavirus as of October 22. â¢While these tests are fast â a result should be available within 15-30 minutes â and relatively cheap, they also have some drawbacks. â¢Health Minister Anschober stressed that they cannot replace the much more accurate PCR test, but complement it. â¢Concretely, the specificity of antigen tests is very high (approaching 100%), while their sensitivity is lower (around 95%). â¢That means that all people testing positive can be practically certain their result is correct; but for those testing negative, there is still a residual chance that they may be positive after all. Link: https://archive.vn/zpRsC

On October 23, The Austrian governmentâs Corona-Ampel colors the country mostly in orange and red, the two highest alert levels. â¢	Almost all districts in Tyrol, Salzburg, and half of those in Upper Austria are red. â¢	Vorarlberg, Vienna, Styria, Lower Austria, and Burgenland are mostly orange, with some red, yellow, and also green areas. â¢	Only Carinthia is still mostly yellow, with some orange and green districts, too. â¢	The map has completely changed in the last 6 weeks, from one dominated by green to one predominantly orange and red. â¢	In total, 21 new districts were switched to red by the Corona Commission. Link: https://archive.vn/zpRsC

At the national level: from October 23, Professional events, such as soccer games or opera performances, are required to have placed seating. Only 1,500 people are allowed outdoor and 1,000 indoor. Masks must be worn during the entire duration of the event. No drinks or food will be offered. Link: https://archive.vn/zpRsC

From October 23, the following rules/measures go into effect:  - No more than six people are allowed to attend indoor meetings (outside of work), such as yoga courses, birthday parties, and weddings. Funerals are exempt from this order.  - Outdoor meetings are limited to 12 people. No further restrictions apply. At restaurants, the maximum number of people at a table is limited to six.  Link: https://archive.vn/zpRsC

No more than two people per row of seats are allowed to travel. This means a family of four cannot give someone from a different household a lift in a five-seater car. The same rules apply to carpools or other ride-sharing arrangements. The regulation does not apply to taxis and mass transport, although anyone traveling in taxis or on mass transport will be required to wear a mask at all times.  Link: https://archive.vn/ACqcb

Masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces. One important change this week is that masks must fit snuglyâ. This means that other forms of face protection - for instance, plastic face shields - will not suffice.   Link: https://archive.vn/zi875

On October 24, Vienna Airport and Austrian Airlines made their first test run with the rapid coronavirus antigen tests planned to be rolled out over the coming weeks. â¢	Passengers on the flight OS 229 to Berlin were tested. â¢	It takes between 10-15 for the results to be available. They will be sent to passengers via e-mail, SMS, or can be inquired about at the counter of Austrian Airlines. â¢The rapid antigen test does not replace the requirement for a negative PCR test that many countries have instituted; however, it does help to make flying safer (people who test positive canât board the train) and gives a strong indication of oneâs status. Link: https://archive.vn/zpRsC

The practice of contact tracing â long seen as the ideal way to break infection chains early â is under strain under the massive count of new cases in recent weeks. In Tyrol, contact tracing will not trace all new infections anymore but just focus on those where a chain of infections can be quickly identified. In Carinthia, the regional government is now looking to hire students to help with contact tracing. Meanwhile, Vorarlberg has accepted an offer from the Austrian Society for Health and Nutrition Safety (AGES) to provide 30 additional employees to help with contact tracing.   Link: https://archive.vn/zpRsC

COVID-19 testing is available in Baku. Individuals are responsible for the entire cost of COVID-19 tests and the cost is in the range of 100 AZN.  The labs listed on AZALâs website are accredited by the Management Union of Medical Territorial Units (TABIB) to offer COVID-19 tests. Active case finding and event-based surveillance for influenza-like illness were activated in early March and any gaps in active case finding and event-based surveillance systems were assessed. The current surveillance strategy is based on the rapid identification and isolation of suspected cases and contact tracing. Surveillance for COVID-19 is conducted jointly by TABIB (Management Union of the Medical Territorial Unions) under the State Mandatory Health Insurance Agency and the Ministry of Health. TABIB is responsible for collecting the information about the new cases, which is being then transmitted to MoH for joint analysis of the cases and situation. Single unified database for COVID-19 has been developed to collect information. The Republican Center for Hygiene and Epidemiology together with TABIB is conducting contact tracing.    Enhanced existing surveillance systems to enable monitoring of COVID-19 transmission. Particularly with establishing active surveillance in areas close to Iranian border and particularly those visited by the two UK cases, and establishing screening protocols for testing of suspected contacts.    A new E-T?BIB (e-TABIB) mobile phone application has been introduced to keep track of people who may have COVID-19. It is free and available in the Google Play Market and AppStore. A notice will be sent to those who are likely to have been exposed to COVID-19 and they will be invited to conduct a test.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201018232035/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/azerbaijan/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Chapter

For the most part, the contract tracing system continues as it did before. Face masks remain mandatory in public spaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201025172421/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/azerbaijan/coronavirus

On 23rd September the Prime Minister announced that for people returning from vacation:  As of Friday, 25th September, going to the red zone will be strongly discouraged and but no longer forbidden. Travellers returning from orange zones will no longer be tested.  Travellers returning from red zones will have to self-quarantine from the  1st day of their return and will need to be tested on the 5th day. This obligation does not apply if people complete a self-assessment document which, after analysis, authorises them to do so. These instructions do not apply to people who spend less than 48 hours in a red zone, such as cross-border workers.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928202006/https://www.premier.be/en/launch-risk-management-strategy-accountability-citizens

http://Although, The National Security Council (NSC) lifted the obligation to wear a mask out of doors at all times On 23rd September, The government of Brussels region has introduced variant measures of its own which are more strict. From 1st October, It will be compulsory to have a mask covering the nose and the mouth on oneself at all times , to be able to put it on as soon as one arrives in a compulsory wearing zone. Outside these areas, wearing a mask is strongly recommended as soon as the situation does not allow physical distancing to be respected. It will also be compulsory to wear the mask covering the nose and mouth in shopping areas and around schools ; these zones and the hours of application of the wearing obligation will be fixed, for each municipality, by the mayors. web.archive.org/web/20200929022021/https://rudivervoort.brussels/news_/la-cellule-de-crise-provinciale-decide-de-nouvelles-mesures-pour-enrayer-la-progression-des-contaminations-en-region-bruxelloise/

A ban on certain countries still applies. However Belgium has eased its travel restrictions on some "red" countries.    "Click on the country or region where you are staying to find out what the conditions are when you return to Belgium.    These are the possibilities :    A COVID test and a quarantine are mandatory;  A COVID test and a quarantine are recommended;  A COVID test and a quarantine are not mandatory on return to Belgium.  Transit is possible, by any means of transport, without conditions or measures upon arrival in Belgium, including travel through red zones.    If you have any questions regarding the Passenger Locator Form, the COVID-19 test and the quarantine obligation in Belgium, please contact the FPS Public Health on 0800 14 689 or send an e-mail to info.coronavirus@health.fgov.be(link is external)."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201010014221/https://diplomatie.belgium.be/en      "On September 25, a ban on travel to countries or regions with high infection rates, or 'Red Zones', was replaced by strong discouragement not to travel to these areas. "On September 23, the government largely eased restrictions, despite a recent increase in reported cases in the country. Could not find confirmation that the income support was still in place in October.        While the measures noted in the last coding update are still in place, they do not seem to describe a general income support of more than 50% lost salary.  However, found an article about income support for cultural workers. Whether that amounts to over or under 50% of regular income is not clear from this article. It is also not entirely clear whether those cultural workers are formal or not, but I am making an assumption that they are contracted and therefore formal.  So there is more than 0 income support, but I canât find evidence for general income support. So coding as 1.  https://archive.vn/Fp3at

They are defined holders of a Bulgarian long-stay visa type "D", as well as persons who have a residence permit in a Member State of the European Union, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, or in a Schengen country (including the Republic of San Marino, Principality of Andorra , The Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and members of their families. They are defined holders of a Bulgarian long-stay visa type "D", as well as persons who have a residence permit in a Member State of the European Union, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, or in a Schengen country (including the Republic of San Marino, Principality of Andorra , The Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and members of their families."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201017071615/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Based on new coding guidance:  1)	Schools are open at all levels, but with alterations, so selected 1.    2)	Public health precautions in schools are decided at the canton level, for each of the 26 cantons, so coding as  "Targeted". (see article 5 in the decree by the Swiss federal council regarding the combat of Coronavirus).   https://archive.vn/5XYU5    E.g. the canton Bern has decreed a range of protective measures such as phased recess, hygiene measures, no handshakes, increased ventilation etc.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200826184719/https://www.erz.be.ch/erz/de/index/kindergarten_volksschule/kindergarten_volksschule/corona/schuljahr-2020-21.assetref/dam/documents/ERZ/AKVB/de/00_Allgemeines/allgemeines_volksschule_corona_leitfaden_praesenzunterricht_mit_schutzmassnahmen_d.pdf    Looking at a sample of other cantons, similar measures are in place:  Zurich: https://archive.vn/wip/CN4uI  Ticino: https://archive.vn/MZutu  Schaffhausen: https://archive.vn/wip/Oi65r    This page has a map with links to each cantonâs coronavirus regulations including schools:  https://archive.vn/wip/22Q2M

At a national level, no required workplace closing, only a requirement to implement protection measures.  At a canton level, Vaud continues to require clubs and discos remain closed until 30th Oct.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201018154337/https://www.vd.ch/fileadmin/user_upload/themes/economie_emploi/entreprises/Q_A_Entreprises.pdf#%5B%7B%22num%22%3A7%2C%22gen%22%3A0%7D%2C%7B%22name%22%3A%22XYZ%22%7D%2C70%2C770%2C0%5D  (section 1.3.4)  It is worth noting that none of the other cantons seem to have introduced required closing for any sector of the economy.

In certain cantons like Aargau, event attendees need to be broken up into sections of 100 people.  https://archive.vn/wip/fwkCi  I cannot find evidence for any Canton that public events are required to be cancelled.

Nationally, working from home is now recommended again.     Working from home recommended  The Federal Council has added a paragraph on working from home to the Special Situation COVID-19 Ordinance. Employers are now required to observe the recommendation by the Federal Office of Public Health for employees to work from home. This will prevent large numbers of people coming together, particularly at peak times, and reduce close contact in the workplace. It will also reduce the risk of a whole work team having to go into quarantine if one member becomes infected with COVID-19.    https://archive.vn/2fyBb#selection-2331.0-2335.491    While this would indicate 1G, due to the continued required closing on clubs and discos in Vaud, keeping the coding at 2T.

The requirement for persons over the age of 12 to wear a mask on public transport has been in place since 6 July. From Monday 19 October this will be extended to railway stations including platforms, airports and other publicly accessible public transport areas. As before, persons who are unable to wear a mask for medical reasons are exempt from the requirement.  Masks are now also compulsory in publicly accessible indoor spaces including all shops, shopping centres, banks, post offices, museums, libraries, cinemas, theatres, concert venues, indoor areas of zoos and botanical gardens, restaurants, bars, discos, casinos, hotels (with the exception of guestsâ rooms), entrance areas and changing rooms in swimming pools, sports facilities and gyms, doctorâs surgeries, hospitals and places of worship, advisory centres and neighbourhood centres. Masks must also be worn in publicly accessible areas of administrative buildings.  Face masks must also be worn in all schools and higher education establishments, in child-care facilities and in the training areas of sport and fitness centres if part of the centreâs precautionary measures.    https://archive.vn/2fyBb

The Ministry of Health of Cyprus announces on 7 October that the validity of the  measures imposed in Larnaca District from 23 September 2020 is renewed until midnight, October 14. From Friday, October 9, 2020:  - Indoor swimming pools, gyms and fitness centres must close.  - Restaurants must close by 20:00 and a maximum of 4 people can sit by one table.  - In the food courts areas in shopping centres a maximum of 2 people can sit by one table. Public Wi-Fi will not be available there. Also a group of maximum of 2 people can enter the shopping centre.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020081103/https://www.osu.eu/24712/the-latest-covid-19-related-news/

The State of Emergency will go into effect from Monday, October 5, 2020, and will last for 30 days. It will help the government to implement new measures quickly.  - The secondary schools from red or orange districts in the Czech traffic light map will switch to distance learning.  - Secondary schools and universities will switch to online learning if have not already done so. The practical and clinical training is an exception. Upper grades of primary schools will split pupils into two groups which will take turns in in-school and distance learning.  - There will be two additional days off for the students on Monday, October 26, and Tuesday, October 27. October 28 is a national holiday.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020081103/https://www.osu.eu/24712/the-latest-covid-19-related-news/

From Monday, October 12, 2020 for 14 days (then they will be either extended or relaxed):  - Public offices will limit their office hours for public to two days a week and five hours a day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020081103/https://www.osu.eu/24712/the-latest-covid-19-related-news/

From Monday, October 12, 2020 for 14 days (then they will be either extended or relaxed):  - All theatres and cinemas must close as well as all other venues organizing cultural events.  Zoos will have to be closed.  - No visits to health and social care facilities are allowed except for precisely specified cases.  - Indoor events will be limited to 10 people, outdoor to 20. There is an exception for employees, entrepreneurs and business meetings.

From Wednesday, October 14, the Czech government announced additional measures to be effective, due to the increasing number of COVID-19 infection cases.  - The lower grades of primary schools will be closed as well and will switch to distance learning. Kindergartens will remain open.  - Student dorms should be closed for students with permanent residence elsewhere in the Czech Republic. There are exceptions for students with mandatory work duties, medical students helping out in hospitals or those involved in training practice. International students may stay at the dorms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020081103/https://www.osu.eu/24712/the-latest-covid-19-related-news/

From Wednesday, October 14, the Czech government announced additional measures to be effective, due to the increasing number of COVID-19 infection cases  - Both indoor and outdoor gatherings are limited to six people.  - There will be closure of pubs, bars and restaurants. They may still operate on a delivery and takeaway basis, however even the takeaway windows must close by 20:00.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020081103/https://www.osu.eu/24712/the-latest-covid-19-related-news/

The German government does not generally require workplaces to close, but advises employees to work from home when possible. However, most workplaces remain open, meaning most people are required to be physically present at work. Nonetheless, high-risk areas in Germany (e.g. regions with more than 50 cases per 100,000 inhabitants) experience, different regulations, which frequently limit the amount of workers allowed in the workplace/office. Still, most employers only work with recommendations and not clearly laid out requirements, meaning people in Germany are still allowed to come to work even when working in high-risk regions.     However, some areas of work (like nightclubs) are still required to remain closed due to associated high risk of potentially spreading the virus when remaining open.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201021184818/https://www.bmas.de/DE/Schwerpunkte/Informationen-Corona/Fragen-und-Antworten/Fragen-und-Antworten-corona/corona-virus-arbeitsrechtliche-auswirkungen.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201021185804/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/faq-reisen-1735032  https://web.archive.org/web/20201021190405/https://www.deutschlandfunk.de/covid-19-wie-es-um-diskotheken-und-clubs-in-der-coronakrise.1939.de.html?drn%3Anews_id=1185564

No change since August 27. Public events are still limited or need to be cancelled. These measures are planned to remain in place until end December this year. Only specific events are allowed, which  1) have fewer than stated max. amount of people (set by each state individually) and 2) have laid out their own hygiene measures.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201021190801/https://evvc.org/article/update-aktuelle-information-zum-coronavirus-auswirkungen-auf-veranstaltungen

No change.   New regulations announced on the 29th of September, create clear guidelines for when gatherings in an area might be required to be diminished, based on the severity of cases in a region. This is based on how high out of 100'000 the cases are over a 7-day period. This includes a recommendation not to have gatherings inside of over 10 people in the case of higher infections in one's area.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201005220735/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-massnahmen-1734724
No measures in place at this moment.

Teachers in secondary and adult education who teach in more than two classes / teams during a day must wear bandages or visors.  Teachers and educators have the right to use visors in day care and primary school if they wish.â  âIn addition, it is still recommended to cancel events with accommodation such as colonies, camp schools and study trips.â Source: https://archive.vn/e4ynB  Furthermore, guidance universities, such as Aarhus University, have put in place to ensure social distancing and additional hygiene precautions still current include: âSanitise your hands whenever you enter a building, and whenever you enter a new room.â âArrive at the classroom no earlier than ten minutes before your class starts.â âWhen you use group rooms, study spaces etcâ¦donât move tables, chair, etc.â Source: https://archive.vn/1Gx3a

Open countries include mostly other Nordic countries and the Schengen Area. Schools have not been closed in general since before the summer vacation. A school can choose to close for a short period due to Covid-19 cases in the school amongst teachers or pupils just to avoid further spreading the virus.   On a press meeting on October 23rd the prime minister announced new restriction. As part of her speech she pointed out that it is a priority for the government to keep schools open.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

On October 23rd the prime minister announced new restrictions. As part of this announcement she said that it is still recommended that employees in public and private companies work from home if it is possible.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik
Before the announcement on October 23rd you were only allowed to be in groups of up to 50 people
Public transportation is still running but you need to wear a mask.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

At a press conference on October 23rd the prime minister announced new restrictions. At the same time she made it clear that it is a priority for the government to keep the businesses in Denmark running including shops, restaurants etc. No recommendation to stay at home was given and it has also not been the case since before the summer vacation.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

Persons resident in countries/regions classified as banned can enter Denmark if they have a worthy purpose. If you arrive from a 'high-risk country' within the EU and the Schengen area as well as the United Kingdom or from at 'banned country' outside the EU or the Schengen area or the United Kingdom, you are required to present proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before entry. On this page you will find information about rules and required documents.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://um.dk/da/rejse-og-ophold/rejse-til-udlandet/coronavirus/

To avoid people are getting fired it is possible as a company to seek compensation for lost revenue as a consequence of restrictions. You can get up to 90% in compensation for certain employees.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://virksomhedsguiden.dk/erhvervsfremme/content/temaer/coronavirus_og_din_virksomhed/ydelser/faa-hjaelp-til-loenudgifter-loenkompensation/eba83819-a5c6-4967-8c04-eae3cee2973d/

A public campaign has been running in Denmark since March 2020. It includes promotion on Social Media with advise from the Health authorities on how to avoid getting Covid-19. A Corona badge has also been offered to all citizens in Denmark - when you wear it you remind other people to keep a safe distance. Posters have been made available in many language for download and print showing an overview of current restrictions, reminding to keep the safe distance, wash your hands etc. There is one site where all the information is being made available for the public:   https://web.archive.org/save/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

If you have been tested positive for Covid-19 the Health authorities will contact you and support you in making sure all your close connections are being asked to also get a test.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://coronasmitte.dk/coronaopsporing

At a press conference on October 23rd the prime minister announced new restrictions which are implemented from October 26th. As part of these restrictions you cannot be in groups with more that 10 people. However, it is allowed to have conferences or sport events with up to 500 people if they all sit looking in the same direction.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

On a press conference on October 23rd the prime minister announced new restrictions which are implemented from October 26rd. As part of these restrictions you are no longer allowed to be in groups with more than 10 people both in private homes and public places.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://coronasmitte.dk/overblik

On October 23rd the prime minister announced new restrictions to be implemented from October 26th. These included a requirement to wear facial coverings in most public places including public transportation, shops, restaurants (when not sitting down), schools (when not sitting down) etc.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://laegemiddelstyrelsen.dk/da/nyheder/2020/fem-mio-borgere-kan-vaccineres-med-tredje-covid-19-vaccineaftale-alene/

On September 30, the Ministry of Health (Ministerio de Sanidad) announces that the Government and Autonomous Communities (CCAA) stating, "Populations with more than 100,000 inhabitants that have an incidence of more than 500 cases per 100,000 people in the last 14 days, a positivity of diagnostic tests for active infection greater than 10% and that are in CCAA with an ICU bed occupancy per Covid-19 patients greater than 35% of the usual allocation will have to take special measures."    Special measures include strict restriction of entry and exit of people from the affected municipalities. Circulation on highways and roads that pass or cross these municipalities will be allowed as long as it has its origin and destination outside of them. No evident policy change.    Estonia admits people with no Covid-19 symptoms arriving from the European Union, the members of the Schengen area or the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, as well as from a small number of countries outside this area - but quarantine requirements may apply.    From Monday, 19 October - in situations where the infection rate of countries is higher than 1.1x the Estonian average, or above 50, a person is allowed to come to Estonia from Latvia, Lithuania or Finland without the self-isolation obligation, if the person has taken a coronavirus test within 48 hours before arriving to Estonia, and the result of the test has been negative. At that, it must be taken into account that the person must not have travelled outside the Baltic states or Finland in the past two weeks.    At the border crossing points, i.e. ports, airports and checkpoints at Russian land borders, the travel documents and medical symptoms are checked. Border control personnel have legal rights to deny entering for persons who show symptoms of COVID-19, i.e. to deport them back to the country of arrival. A person entering Estonia from a country to which the quarantine requirements apply will have to provide the Police and Border Guard Board their address and confirm that they will remain at their place of stay for 14 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201023010834/https://vm.ee/en/information-countries-and-quarantine-requirements-passengers    https://web.archive.org/web/20201023004230/https://www.visitestonia.com/en/why-estonia/coronavirus-and-travelling-to-estonia

No apparent policy change.     Some restrictions are still in place.    No more than 750 persons may participate in an indoor event. The amount public in outdoor events may be up to 2000 persons (unless a special permission is granted by the Health Board together with local governmental unit and The Government's working committee). Disinfectants must be provided and the dispersion requirement must be followed.    The restriction of 50% occupancy is still in force for all such premises, that do not provide stationary seating places for all members of the audience. Additionally in order to limit the risk of contagion, visitors must be distributed at entrances and exits, bathrooms, leisure areas, and other more popular gathering places.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201023004230/https://www.visitestonia.com/en/why-estonia/coronavirus-and-travelling-to-estonia

For further details visit the THL website."    https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/finland/coronavirus    "Do you have to wear a mask if you spend only a little time in a public indoor space?  Do you have to wear a mask if you can keep enough distance to other people?  According to the recommendation, you must wear a mask if you are unable to keep enough distance from other people, which means that you can use discretion based on the situation.    There are situations where customers and staff have been protected by other safety arrangements, such as protective shields.    Regional authorities provide instructions about wearing masks based on the situation in the local area (municipality or hospital district).    What is meant by public transport?  Public transport includes modes of public transport such as buses, trams, metros, ships, and airplanes.    When should you put on a mask?  Put on a mask before entering public transport or a public indoor space in accordance with regional guidelines."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201010155109/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/recommendation-on-the-use-of-face-masks-for-citizens/questions-and-answers-about-face-masks

Current Restrictions: https://web.archive.org/web/20201023020124/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions  Regional situations, restrictions and recommendations: https://web.archive.org/web/20201023020145/https://thl.fi/fi/web/infektiotaudit-ja-rokotukset/ajankohtaista/ajankohtaista-koronaviruksesta-covid-19/tilannekatsaus-koronaviruksesta/koronaepidemia-alueiden-tilanne-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset    The Government recommends working remotely to the extent possible in both the public and private sectors. Current Restrictions: https://web.archive.org/web/20201023020124/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions   Regional situations, restrictions and recommendations: https://web.archive.org/web/20201023020145/https://thl.fi/fi/web/infektiotaudit-ja-rokotukset/ajankohtaista/ajankohtaista-koronaviruksesta-covid-19/tilannekatsaus-koronaviruksesta/koronaepidemia-alueiden-tilanne-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset     I have given Targeted rating for the code as Ostrobothnia region is in Spreading Phase and multiple regions are in Accelerated Phase [South Ostrobothnia, Pirkanmaa, Kante-Haame, Varsinais-Suomi, Aland, Helsinki-Uusimaa] which means the following restrictions are in place:     Spreading phase of the epidemic  regional or local recommendation to avoid private events with more than 10 persons  if necessary, public events may be prohibited altogether  if group leisure activities are suspended altogether, special discretion should be exercised with regard to childrenâs and young peopleâs hobbies  if necessary, public spaces may be closed down altogether.    Acceleration phase of the epidemic  regional or local recommendation to avoid private events with more than 20 persons  number of persons at public events restricted to half (50 per cent) of the normal capacity  number of customers in public spaces restricted to half (50 per cent) of the normal capacities and spaces used in such a way that participants and parties can avoid close contact   adult group leisure activities indoors are suspended if the risk of infection is high  all leisure activities must be organised in such a way that participants and parties can avoid close contact.    Base level of the epidemic  public events with more than 50 persons permitted; organisers must ensure compliance with the guidelines from THL and the Ministry of Education and Culture  leisure activities and the use of public spaces should be arranged so that participants and parties can avoid close contact

Current Restrictions: https://web.archive.org/web/20201023020124/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions  Regional situations, restrictions and recommendations: https://web.archive.org/web/20201023020145/https://thl.fi/fi/web/infektiotaudit-ja-rokotukset/ajankohtaista/ajankohtaista-koronaviruksesta-covid-19/tilannekatsaus-koronaviruksesta/koronaepidemia-alueiden-tilanne-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset    Travel within Finland is allowed as long as health and safety guidelines relating to coronavirus are observed.    All travel must be avoided when ill. During travel, it is important to observe good hand and respiratory hygiene. It is important to avoid unnecessary physical contact Tourism businesses must pay particular attention to cleaning, preparedness planning and training of staff.

https://web.archive.org/web/20201023022106/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/entry-restrictions    Restrictions on border traffic from 12 October  Restrictions on internal border traffic will be in force for traffic between Finland and Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland, apart from certain exceptions.     External border traffic refers to traffic between Finland and non-Schengen countries. External border traffic will be permitted only for traffic arriving in Finland from the Vatican, and for traffic between Finland and Australia, Japan, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, New Zealand and Uruguay for residents of these countries.    In addition, people may come to Finland from the following European countries for work or another essential reason: Andorra, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Ireland, Monaco, Romania, San Marino and the United Kingdom.    For all other non-Schengen countries, restrictions on entry allow only return traffic to Finland and other EU and Schengen countries, transit traffic at Helsinki Airport and other essential traffic.

âSelf-employed persons can get labour market subsidy payments if they have stopped working as self-employed or if their income from self-employment is less than EUR 1,089.67 per month because of the coronavirus epidemic. You donât need to end your self-employment business to qualify for unemployment benefits.â  âI have a zero-hour contract. Because of the coronavirus situation, I havenât been given any more shifts. Am I entitled to basic social assistance from Kela?â âIf you apply for basic social assistance, Kela will also assess your right to social assistance. When making an assessment, Kela takes your earned income into account. Note that you have an obligation to prepare for a possible reduction in earnings. Kela will, however, consider each case individually and assess the extent to which a person can realistically be expected to prepare for unexpected situations. Kela will also take the exceptional situation caused by the coronavirus epidemic into account.â  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200909193116/https://www.kela.fi/web/en/corona-frequently-asked-questions  âIf you are laid off temporarily, you can get unemployment benefits from your unemployment fund or from Kela. Being laid off temporarily, or furloughed, means that you do not work and are not paid, but your employment contract remains in force. The temporary lay-off may be for a specific period of time or until further notice.â Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200909195651/https://www.kela.fi/web/en/temporary-lay-off

These are the two zones placed on maximum alert.Â   https://web.archive.org/web/20200926094132/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/europe/france-to-roll-out-new-measures-as-covid-19-surges/1983688

In regions on maximum alert then there are no large public gatherings allowed. The localisation of COVID responses with different alert zones in different departments is an even stronger recommendation to avoid critical zones.

"Travel in Greece  It is mandatory to wear face-masks on public transport (including flights and ferries), at airports and in taxis.    Travel in a private car or a taxi is limited to a maximum of 3 adult passengers per vehicle, in addition to the driver. Any children in the vehicle do not count towards this limit. When travelling in a taxi, all passengers must wear face-masks.    Travel to and from islands  You may travel throughout Greece, including to the islands.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding; and it is obligatory to wear masks on all ferries, including on open air decks, where capacity is limited to allow for social distancing. No celebrations are allowed on board ferries.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, you are also required to wear masks throughout the journey. Specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.    Since 1 August, cruise ships can dock at Piraeus, Rhodes, Heraklion, Volos, Corfu and Katakolo. After their first docking, the ships may visit any other Greek port on their itinerary. Rules will be kept under review.    Travel by private sailboats (and yachts) is now permitted within Greece. If your vessel is arriving in Greece from another country, you must comply with specific requirements upon your first landing in Greece. No passengers are permitted on the vessel, except for the crew. Upon arrival, you must present to harbour authorities, who will require the completion of a health declaration, and mandatory testing (to be paid for by the occupants of each vessel)."   http://web.archive.org/web/20201011054526/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

There is no projected date when entry will be permitted."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201011055633/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    British nationals are not affected by the European Unionâs measures to close EU borders to non-EU country nationals. Executive Order nr 37 from 29 September regarding travelling to and in Greenland is valid from 30 September 2020 through 31 January 2021.    Entrance requirements:  - Upon check-in one must show a maximum 5 day old negative Corona test.  - They must also show a confirmation of the completed Sumut form, a personal locator form, which advises where you will be visiting and whom you will come in contact with. This form can be downloaded at www.sumut2020.    Due to the high Reproduction factor in Denmark and other countries, the earlier quarantine rules are now back in effect. This means that all travellers upon arrival in Greenland must:    - go into 14 days quarantine if you are not re-tested in Greenland.  - go into quarantine until receipt of a negative re-test result, which can be first conducted on day 5 after arrival.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://visitgreenland.com/articles/corona-virus-status/

In Greenland, you are required to wear a bandage(mask) in the following situations:    1. For international and domestic flights.  This applies to everyone over the age of 12 as well as the cabin crew, with a few exceptions when on the plane, staying at airports or terminal areas.  When employed with passenger contact in terminal areas and the like, you must wear a bandage or visor if a plastic screen cannot be set up between employees and travelers. Reference is also made to Â§ 6 and Â§ 7 Self-Government Executive Order no. 37 of 29 September 2020 on conditions for travel to and in Greenland  2. If you are infected or at risk of being infected with a new coronavirus and exceptionally have to move out, eg because you need to be tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201006064205/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/rejser_til_groenland_fra_den_15_juni?sc_lang=da

Naalakkersuisut has established aid packages to support business and employees through the COVID-19 period:  Business support package for small and medium-sized enterprises in Greenland (SMEs) on the basis of COVID-19 Part 1 (Emergency Package), including Activity Package for the Tourism Industry and Mobility Package  Business support package for small and medium-sized enterprises in Greenland (SMEs) based on COVID-19 part 2 (General Package)  Aid package for workers (wage compensation for private companies)  Activity package for the tourism industry (grants for hotel nights and adventure tours)  Mobility package (subsidy for scheduled tickets)  Fisheries package (subsidy for coastal fisheries)  The following help packages expire september 30, 2020:  Business support package for small and medium-sized enterprises in Greenland (SMEs) based on COVID-19 part 2 (General Package)  Aid package for workers (wage compensation for private companies)  Mobility package (subsidy for scheduled tickets)  The following help packages expire december 31, 2021:  Business support package for small and medium-sized enterprises in Greenland (SMEs) on the basis of COVID-19 Part 1 (Emergency Package), including Activity Package for the Tourism Industry and Mobility Package  Activity package for the tourism industry (grants for hotel nights and adventure tours)  Fisheries package (subsidy for coastal fisheries)  https://web.archive.org/web/20201022180135/https://www.businessingreenland.gl/da/COVID-19

Vulnerable PlacesÂ are those one CANNOT travel to without first:Â   Having undergone quarantine in an Open Place on the 5th day after arrival. The ban on participation from other countries and municipalities also covers events such as courses, seminars and the like. It is possible to hold public events within current municipal boundaries with certain restrictions. It is the organizer's responsibility to ensure that there is no participation from people from other municipalities, or that this is encouraged.  Courses can still be run with external teachers, as long as the participants are from the same municipalityâ  âThere must be a maximum of 100 people for an indoor event, provided that the rules on occupancy in the room itself of a maximum of 50% of what is allowed are also complied with. For outdoor events, there can be a maximum of 250 people. The executive order is valid until and including 31 January 2021.â Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201019195758/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/07/310720-Midlertidige-restriktioner-ved-forsamlinger-mv-forlaenges

People in risk groups are not being strongly recommended to shield at home. However, in response to âWhat should you do if you belong to a particular risk group?â Health authorities have recommended: âthink about how you can protect yourself as much as possible from becoming infectedâ, including   âStay at home as much as possible.   Avoid places with a lot of people. We advise against e.g. that you use public transport especially during rush hour.â Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201019214454/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/risikogrupper_og_saerligt_saarbare?sc_lang=da

Travellers to certain areas must be quarantined in the last town on the trip, where there is a health center. The quarantine must be carried out in the places mentioned below until a negative test result is received after inoculation on the 5th day. Then the journey can continue to the final destination.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028120613/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/rejser_til_groenland_fra_den_15_juni?sc_lang=da

All entrants - regardless of age - must have a maximum of five days old negative COVID-19 test at check-in at Kastrup Airport.  This means that arrivals in Greenland must be quarantined for 14 days or re-tested for COVID-19 on the 5th day after arrival or later. http://web.archive.org/web/20201028114742/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/09/2909_covid19
Work package for workers (wage compensation for private companies) expired on 30 September 2020.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028122603/https://www.businessingreenland.gl/da/COVID-19
No measures on debt relief for households found.
The Office of the Medical Director of Health website is being updated with coronavirus information every day.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201028125152/https://www.nun.gl/

Citizens with symptoms who have had or have contact with entrants will be able to be tested.  Selected patient groups who do not belong to a risk group for infection, but who have symptoms of COVID-19 infection, will to a limited extent also be offered testing. This is carried out as part of the monitoring of COVID-19 in Greenland.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028125721/https://www.nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/hvem_bliver_testet_for_covid_19?sc_lang=da

Completion of the Sumut form continues to be a requirement for anyone entering Greenland and âcontains information such as:  Your itinerary  Your destination  Who you will visit or live with  The form is a tool which will be used to track infection cases, if necessary.  The confirmation email for a completed Sumut form will be used as validation for entry to Greenland when booking the COVID-19 test via Rigshospitalet or at check-in at the airport.â  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201028130541/https://sumut2020.gl/Instructions/EditInstructions

In Greenland, it is required that you wear a sanitary napkin in the following situations:  1. For international and domestic flights   2. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201028131548/https://www.nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/rejser_til_groenland_fra_den_15_juni?sc_lang=da

Hungary aims to advance its testing policies:  Hungary plans to launch rapid antigen tests for coronavirus infections possibly as soon as Tuesday, Prime Minister Viktor Orban said on Monday, as testing in the central European country has struggled to keep up with the pace of infections.    Antigen tests detects proteins on the surface of the virus. They require an uncomfortable nasal or throat swab, and can produce results more quickly than PCR tests - which detect genetic material in the virus - but are considered less accurate.  https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSKBN2742DJ

The general regulation from earlier stays in place, yet there are stricter rules on people allowed/visit facilities.    The maximum size of classes in upper secondary schools and universities is 30 persons.    Pre-schools and junior schools: No number restrictions apply to children born in 2005 or later. For those born prior to 2005, the maximum of 30 persons applies to each class, with a social distance of 1 metre; face-masks shall be worn if it is not possible to observe the social distance rule.    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201028104137/https://www.government.is/news/article/2020/10/05/COVID-19-Changes-to-the-rules-on-gathering-sizes-and-schools/

"Number limitation . Restrictions on the number of persons coming together are limited to 20 adults, whether in private or public spaces. This includes:  Conferences, seminars, outdoor meetings, etc.  Teaching, lectures and exams.  Entertainment, such as concerts, cultural events, theatrical performances, cinemas, sporting events and private events.  Church services, such as weddings, confirmations, and other religious gatherings.  Other similar events with more than 20 individuals.  The number limit, general proximity limit and mask obligation do not apply to children born in 2005 or later.    At all workplaces and in all activities, no more than 20 people may be inside the same space at the same time. It must be ensured that there is no communication between spaces.    Stores may have up to 100 people inside at a time as long as it is possible to secure 1 meter between people. Stores that are over 1,000 m2 in size may allow an additional one customer for every 10 sqm that is in excess of this 1,000 sqm. However, the maximum number of customers is always 200.    Up to 50 people may attend the funeral."    "The restriction takes effect on 5 October 2020 and is valid until and including 19 October 2020."    Link: https://archive.fo/YAzzh

Prior regulation stays in place, however, there are new guidlines to social distancing:    Social distance of 2 metres: People not closely related or connected are required to maintain a social distance of 2 metres. This also applies in all schools, though not to pupils born in or after 2005.     http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201028104445/https://www.government.is/news/article/2020/10/07/COVID-19-Stricter-rules-to-combat-infection-in-the-metropolitan-area-/

Masks covering the mouth and nose must be worn where it is not possible to keep a distance of 2 metre from people you do not know by using limits to the number of people. This applies e.g. to public transport, including domestic flights and passenger ferries, and operations such as hair salons and massage parlours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022185626/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/avoding-infecton

In effect is a regulation on limits to schoolwork due to the pandemic which applies as of 19 October 2020 up to and including 10 November 2020. The rules on limits to the number of people and on social distancing do not apply to children born 2005 and later. Limits to school operations apply to pre-school, primary schools, secondary schools, continuing education and universities, in both public and private schools.    Primary schools are permitted to continue schoolwork on condition that employees ensure they maintain the 2 metre social distancing when face masks are not used. No more than 30 individuals born 2004 or earlier may be in the same area. This also applies to after school centres, community centres and sports activities in primary schools.    School work in secondary schools may continue, provided that students and staff can ensure at least 2 metre social distancing and the maximum number of students in each schoolroom does not exceed 30. The mixing of students between groups is not permitted during classes but employees and teachers are permitted to go between groups.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201022180439/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/children

Primary schools:  Primary schools are permitted to continue schoolwork on condition that employees ensure they maintain the 2 metre social distancing when face masks are not used. No more than 30 individuals born 2004 or earlier may be in the same area. This also applies to after school centres, community centres and sports activities in primary schools. As a rule, parents and relatives are not to enter school buildings except when absolutely necessary.    Secondary schools and universities:  School work in secondary schools may continue, provided that students and staff can ensure at least 2 metre social distancing and the maximum number of students in each schoolroom does not exceed 30. The mixing of students between groups is not permitted during classes but employees and teachers are permitted to go between groups. The limit on the number of people and mixing of groups may be departed from in shared premises within the school, such as entrance, foyers, in restrooms and hallways if face masks are used. Under certain circumstance, such as practical classes, art classes, clinical studies, students and teachers must use face masks.    Physical contact between students during training sessions and competition is permitted in sports classes at secondary schools. The 2-metre social distancing rule, however, must be observed in changing rooms and other areas outside competition and training facilities.    Shared contact surfaces in classrooms are to be disinfected after the use of each student group. In addition, shared equipment and contact surfaces are to be disinfected daily and emphasis placed on personal infection prevention measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201028085021/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/children  https://web.archive.org/web/20201028085202/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/what-is-ban-on-public-events

For 20 Oct-10 Nov, only in capital:     Services that require physical contact or close proximity: Any operation and services requiring physical contact between people or close proximity are banned. This includes hair and beauty salons, massage parlours, tattoo parlours, dog grooming salons, tanning salons and other equivalent operations. The aforementioned does not include operations that provide health care services, where wearing a mask is mandatory. The restrictions do not apply to domestic flights and ferries, taxis, buses or public transport.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201022182748/https://www.covid.is/categories/could-you-be-infected

The restrictions enter into effect on 20 October 2020 and will remain in effect up to and including 10 November 2020.    Capital area: ?Stricter rules in the metropolitan area:  Sports, youth activities and hobbies of children of kindergarten and primary school age are forbidden. This includes school swimming lessons that require physical contact and further mixing of group    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022182748/https://www.covid.is/categories/could-you-be-infected    Effective restrictions on gatherings throughout Iceland excluding the capital area:    Main measures that apply:  Gatherings still allowed. However, limits to the number of people. There is a 20-person limit on the number of adults in a gathering, both in private and public areas. This applies to:    Conferences, symposiums, outdoor meetings, etc.  Teaching, lectures and exams.  Entertainment, such as concerts, cultural events, theatrical plays, cinema shows, sports competitions and private events.  Church services, such as weddings, confirmations and other religious events.  Other comparable events with more than 20 individuals.    Up to 50 persons may attend funerals, 20 persons may attend funeral receptions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022181215/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/what-is-ban-on-public-events

Gatherings where 20 persons or fewer come together are permitted, both in public and private spaces. These rules enter into effect on 20 October 2020 and will remain in effect up to and including 10 November 2020:    Facemasks covering the mouth and nose must be used in locations where the 2-metre distance rule between persons cannot be followed. This applies to e.g. healthcare services, hair salons and massage parlours, in domestic flights and passenger ferries, in taxis and coaches as well as in public transport. It is important to read the instructions on the use of facemasks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201028085202/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/what-is-ban-on-public-events

The new Decree signed 13 October 2020 strongly recommends avoiding parties and avoiding meetings between more than *6* non-cohabiting persons in private homes. Parties following civil or religious ceremonies can be held with the maximum participation of *30* people in accordance with the protocols and guidelines. Access to places of worship is permitted so long as social distance protocols can be followed (1 meter).    Indoor sporting events are still limited to 200 spectators as previously noted; however, this indicator is meant to code private gatherings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201013210123/http://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioNotizieNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&menu=notizie&p=dalministero&id=5119

No change in policy found.    COVID-19 testing procedures in Italy vary by region, and individuals should consult regional health authorities for further guidance. Generally, the first step is a blood test (serological test) to identify the presence of antibodies that are found in the blood following contact with the virus. To carry out this test, it is necessary to go to an authorized public or private laboratory with a prescription from a physician. This test costs approximately 15 Euro and is paid for by the individual being tested. In the event of a positive response to the blood test, a nasal swab test (oropharyngeal test) should be promptly carried out to determine if the infection is active or if there is risk of transmitted it to others. The nasal swab test is coordinated by the Italian National Health System (SSN) at no charge to the person tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201013215656/https://it.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Contract tracing app does not qualify this indicator to be coded as "comprehensive" as participation in downloading the app is voluntary and many citizens are apprehensive to participate over privacy concerns. The new Decree, signed 13 October 2020, states that it is mandatory, throughout the country, to carry the airway protection devices with them and to wear them in places other than private homes and in all outdoor places except in cases where, for the characteristics of the places or for the circumstances of fact, be guaranteed continuously the condition of isolation with respect to non-cohabiting people, and in any case with salvation of the protocols and anti-contagion guidelines provided for economic, productive, administrative and social activities, as well as guidelines for the consumption of food and drink.    Excluded from the above obligations:    individuals who are doing sports  children under the age of six,  individuals with pathologies or disabilities incompatible with the use of the mask, as well as for those who, in order to interact with them, pour into the same incompatibility.    Community masks can be used.    The Decree strongly recommends the use of airway protection devices even within private homes in the presence of non-cohabiting persons. The use of masks is in addition to other protective measures aimed at reducing contagion, including social distance and hand washing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201013210123/http://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioNotizieNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&menu=notizie&p=dalministero&id=5119

On October 25, the Ministry of Healthcare registered the first COVID-19 cases among children at primary and nursery schools. About 16 children contracted COVID-19 in East-Kazakhstan and North-Kazakhstan. Contacts of those 16 children - parents, teachers, and other children - will be tested for a COVID-19. It should be noted that the government is not conducting contact tracing for all infected people over the country.   Link: https://archive.vn/nmnc0
On September 28, Shymkent city administration extended quarantine until October 12 by limiting movements.  Link: https://archive.vn/R0iQi
On September 28, Shymkent city administration extended quarantine until October 12 by restricting bus movements between Shymkent and other cities/regions.  Link: https://archive.vn/R0iQi

From March 13 to July 26, about 2,5 million people were tested for COVID-19 which is about 13,5 percent of the total population. The government mainly tested senior government officials, patients admitted to hospital, citizens returned from overseas and medical staff.  From March until present, the Kazakhstan government has not implemented any free COVID-19 test policy to the general public.  Link: https://archive.vn/ixsUR

On September 30, the Minister of Healthcare of Kazakhstan urged Mayors of cities and regions to tighten control over the wearing of face masks among citizens. According to Minister, about 1,131 people were fined for not wearing face masks in public areas and public transport from September 5 to September 27.    Link: https://archive.vn/I4oGZ
On October 1, the Minister of Healthcare stated that citizens arriving from overseas (with no COVID-19 test certificate) will be tested.    Link: https://archive.vn/lpp1X

From October 5, the resumption of flights with other countries was suspended, and not allowed to increase the flights with countries that have already resumed flights with Kazakhstan. The government ordered to reduce flights to Turkey.  Link: https://archive.vn/IMsjF

On October 6, a new decree signed by Chief Sanitary Doctor of Kazakhstan Yerlan Kiyasov came into force. According to the degree, all passengers from abroad have to undergo thermometry, fill out a questionnaire, and provide a negative COVID-19 test certificate taken no longer than 72 hours before arrival. Foreign passengers with no COVID-19 certificate are not allowed to enter the country.   Link: https://archive.vn/kcE7D
On October 7, the President of Kazakhstan emphasized the importance of building strong communication with citizens on COVID-19.  Link: https://archive.vn/TmCBC
On October 7, the President of Kazakhstan tasked the government to make a COVID-19 test affordable to the public by lowering the price.  Link: https://archive.vn/0ET8C
On October 9, Shymkent city administration extended quarantine until October 26.  Link: https://archive.vn/QMbun
On October 9, Shymkent city administration extended quarantine until October 26 by restricting bus movements between Shymkent and other cities/regions. Link: https://archive.vn/LQ26F
From October 13, public transport in the Mangistau region will stop operating during weekends.  Link: https://archive.vn/hebQL

On 10 September 2020, the Ministry of Education and Science announced that for the first quarter of this academic year, most of the students will study remotely. There are a few schools that remain to open with sanitation requirements in place.     "It was decided in the first quarter of the academic year to transfer the bulk of the students to a distance format."    "There are 3.4 million students in Kazakhstan, of which 77% of children started learning in a distance format. Taking into account the epidemiological situation, at the first stage, we opened duty classes and small schools with a total contingent of 800 thousand students."    Recent news coverage shows this policy is still in effect.    "96% of the city's students study in a distance format. In 133 schools of the city 923 duty classes have been organized with coverage of 11 840 children."    "The activities of the duty classes are carried out with a capacity of no more than 15 people in strict observance of sanitary and epidemiological requirements."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027083911/https://www.inform.kz/ru/predlozheniya-po-uchebe-v-shtatnom-rezhime-vyrabotalo-minobrazovaniya-rk_a3693001    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027084250/https://www.inform.kz/ru/prichiny-sohraneniya-distancionnogo-obucheniya-v-shkolah-nazval-aleksey-coy_a3693028    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027083238/https://www.coronavirus2020.kz/ru/vosem-almatinskih-shkol-nikov-zaboleli-koronavirusom-vse-oni-uchatsya-distancionno_a3703926

The public transport is operating albeit with limited capacities. For example, in some regions, public transport will not work on Sunday.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027095248/https://www.coronavirus2020.kz/ru/karantinnye-mery-usilivayut-v-pavlodarskoy-oblasti-obschestvennyy-transport-ne-budet-rabotat-v-voskresen-e_a3707256    https://archive.fo/59GzJ

Further money was spent to expand access to PCR testing.     "34 million tenge was spent on PCR testing for arriving air passengers." Besides, the Akimat of Nur-Sultan is implementing a project to adopt 9 isothermal laboratory complexes in city polyclinics for PCR testing.    "This will help increase the number of studies and provide timely assistance more precisely. The total capacity of such complexes is about 1.5 thousand studies per day. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027170344/https://www.coronavirus2020.kz/ru/34-mln-tenge-potratili-na-pcr-testy-dlya-priletevshih-v-kazahstan-passazhirov_a3706219    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027170614/https://www.coronavirus2020.kz/ru/pcr-testirovanie-budut-provodit-v-poliklinikah-nur-sultana_a3706294

Over 2,800 rural schools in remote areas of Kazakhstan continue to operate in strict compliance with the new sanitary and hygiene norms. They provide multi-shift schooling for pupils, whose parents opted in for offline studies.â    https://web.archive.org/web/20201027082249/https://www.unicef.org/eca/stories/education-rural-kazakhstan-during-pandemic

From 26 October 2020, all foreigners arriving in Kazakhstan through international flights must have a certificate of PCR tests for COVID-19. "A British citizen was deported on October 24 this year. from Aktau airport due to the lack of a PCR certificate. "    "Effective October 6, 2020, the Government of Kazakhstan is requiring foreign travelers arriving in Kazakhstan to provide a negative COVID-19 PCR test dated no more than three days prior to their entry to Kazakhstan.  If they are unable to provide negative PCR test results, they will be denied entry. Local medical services in Kyrgyzstan are available but hospitals are starting to fill to capacity. We are currently seeing a surge in cases across the country. Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? No.  Please note that the entry ban on U.S. citizen travelers remains in place. Despite some exceptions to the ban announced by the Kyrgyz government  for the below categories, even travelers who meet one of the exceptions have been denied entry and deported.  Meeting one of the exceptions is not a guarantee that you will be permitted entry.  S. citizen travelers should not plan to travel to the Kyrgyz Republic at this time as you are likely to be denied entry.  Exceptions may be given for:  S. Citizens who hold Kyrgyz permanent residency;  Those who hold a valid Kyrgyz work visa;  Those who have an immediate Kyrgyz relative (spouse, parent, child, or grandchild) and proof of relationship (original documents only, no copies)  University students (with visas and original proof of enrollment).    Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? Yes  Kyrgyzstan now requires travelers to have negative PCR test results dated no more than 72 hours before arrival into Kyrgyzstan. Travelers without valid PCR results will be denied entry    https://web.archive.org/web/20201014082154/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Social institutions  About 490 thousand citizens from socially vulnerable groups will receive social payments from the Government  The government allocated 4459,5 tons of flour  200 million soms allocated for the purchase of food for families from socially vulnerable groups  Workers involved in combatting COVID-19    As of April 10, from the deposit account opened for the Ministry of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic, 433 medical workers were paid compensation payments in the total amount of 3 million 159 thousand soms for March  To avoid the risk of coronavirus infection, the Ministry of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic decided to send on paid labor leave medical workers over 65, pregnant women and employees with small children  About 500 vehicles (buses, minibuses, personal vehicles) are involved in the movement of health workers    https://web.archive.org/web/20201014084854/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/kyrgyzstan-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html

The Ministry of Health is testing only symptomatic patients. Private COVID-19 testing is available for a fee at Bonetsky Laboratory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201014082154/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Ministry of Health uses WHO case definitions for suspected cases, confirmed cases and probable cases. It has adapted a case definition for contact cases. Probable cases are defined as having returned from a high-risk country 14 days before the onset of symptoms. Contacts are defined as having had contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19 infection in the country. Contact tracing is being implemented. So far, the Ministry of Health is able to trace all cases to several clusters. The Ministry of Health is using event and indicator-based surveillance    https://web.archive.org/web/20201014085833/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/kyrgyzstan/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.4+Monitoring+and+surveillance&Type=Section

From October 12 until October 19, Bishkek city announced a curfew due to the latest political developments. The aim of the curfew is to ensure public health security.   Link: https://archive.vn/3GL79

School learners (Grades 2-6) have not returned to schools due to political instability in Kyrgyzstan.  First-grade school learners are continuing attending schools. University and college students studying online.   Link: https://archive.vn/pSj3G https://archive.vn/loWWy
Bars, clubs, movie theaters, and other indoor entertainment facilities remain closed.  Link: https://archive.vn/ESiMK

Large events are prohibited. However, citizens are not complying with this rule. Mass protests are taking place in Kyrgyzstan due to the political situations in the country. Protestors are not following social distancing rules.   Link: https://archive.vn/ccE2h
There are no new updates on whether the government easing the restrictions on gatherings or not.
Is public transportation operating? Yes Bishkek city public transport operates on weekdays and weekends from 7:00 â 23:00. Masks are required on public transit. Link: https://archive.vn/obKlt
The curfew in Bishkek was canceled. Currently, there is no curfew across the country.   Links: https://archive.vn/4664D https://archive.vn/obKlt
Are commercial flights operating? Yes Irregular special commercial flights continue with flights operating to Dubai, Istanbul, and Moscow. Link: https://archive.vn/obKlt

There is no information available on whether the government is still providing income support or not. It can be concluded that Kyrgyzstan is not implementing any policies on income support for those who lost their jobs during the COVID-19 in recent days. The government is supporting vulnerable families. For example, on October 13, the government stated that about 747 million KGS was paid for citizens according to the social support scheme. However, these financial resources were not allocated among those who lost jobs during the pandemic. Following the link, you can find where the government allocated money for.   Link: https://archive.vn/nLBQS

According to the KPMG report, the Kygyztsan government decided to:   - extend the deadline for submitting a single tax return for individuals and individual entrepreneurs until April 1, 2021;  - extend the moratorium on inspections by state regulatory authorities until January 1, 2022;  - introduce a restriction on field tax audits until January 1, 2021;  - recommend to the appropriate organizations within 3 months:  not to cut off electricity, water, gas and other utilities, communications and Internet services, due to the presence of debts of subscribers;  do not charge penalties, penalties for non-payment of utility bills (for electricity, water, gas, garbage collection, communication services, Internet, etc.)  - provide a deferral of payments for the rental of state property for 3 months, from April 1, 2020;  - introduce a temporary ban on conducting bankruptcy proceedings until January 1, 2021.  Link: https://archive.vn/Cjk4o
The Ministry of Healthcare is updating COVID-19 cases on a daily basis. Moreover, the website on COVID-19 https://covid.kg/ is still operating.  https://archive.vn/dfHkE

The Ministry of Health is testing only symptomatic patients. Private COVID-19 testing is available for a fee at Bonetsky Laboratory. 19th October 2020, Self-isolation for 14 days is mandatory upon your arrival from COVID-19 affected countries. Self-isolation could last for 10 days, if a person gets a negative COVID-19 test result after at least 8 days in isolation. It also applies, when COVID-19 affected countries are crossed (by car, public transport, etc.), except air transport, if you do not leave transit area at the airport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201023071734/https://www.govilnius.lt/media-news/important-information-regarding-the-coronavirus

Face masks are mandatory in all indoor public places, including shops, points of service and on public transport. Face masks are also mandatory in all indoor and outdoor events as well as in public catering establishments (restaurants, cafes, bars and other catering establishments). However, visitors to public catering establishments will be able to remove their protective equipment (masks, respirators, shields, etc.) while sitting at a table or bar.    Exceptions:  - Where service cannot be provided to a customer wearing a mask (e.g., beard trimming), the customer will be able to stay without a mask during the provision of the service.  - While exercising in sports clubs and staying in amusement parks (e.g. swimming pools).  - People with disabilities who are unable to wear face and mouth protection due to their disability are exempt. For example, those with respiratory disorders, mental disorders, autism spectrum disorders and others. In cases where a person with a disability (such as movement) can still wear face protection, they should.  - For children under 6 years    https://web.archive.org/web/20201023071734/https://www.govilnius.lt/media-news/important-information-regarding-the-coronavirus
