05.10.2020  Ministry of Health  The Ministry of Health calls: work remotely as far as possible  In Latvia, the incidence of Covid-19 has increased rapidly, so the Ministry of Health invites state and local authorities, as well as private companies, if possible, to organise the work remotely. So far, more frequent outbreaks of Covid-19 have been in the workplace, so it is particularly important to remember the precautions.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/veselibas-ministrija-aicina-iespeju-robezas-stradajiet-attalinati

https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/valdiba-nosaka-stingrakas-prasibas-covid-19-infekcijas-izplatibas-ierobezosanai  https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Open+Sans:400italic,600italic,700italic,400,600,700&subset=latin,cyrillic-ext,latin-ext,cyrillic&q2r92j  On Friday, 9 October 2020, an extraordinary government meeting decided to strengthen the security measures put in place to reduce the risk of covid-19 spread. Amendments to the rules on epidemiological safeguards will enter into force on 10 October.  Events of any kind may only take place in fixed, personalised seats. The maximum number of people who can gather indoors at the same time is 500 and in the open air â 1000. Measures with a high risk of spreading infection are limited â i.e. indoor activities associated with the movement of disorganised people (e.g. dancing) when distance cannot be ensured.

If returning to/entering Latvia!  You must self-isolate if you returning to/entering Latvia from a country which is subject to special precautionary and restrictive measures due to a high number of confirmed Covid-19 cases in the specific country.   The list of countries can be viewed on the website of the Latvian Centre for Disease Prevention and Control - spkc.gov.lv. If the country is marked in red or yellow, a person must self-isolate for a period of 10 days.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.vm.gov.lv/en/ministry/novel_coronavirus_covid19_advice_for_the_public1/

20.10.2020  Ministry of Health  Ministry of Health: priority should be given to medical or hygienic face mask  In order to make the mandatory use of face masks clearer, the government today, 20 October, clarified the text of the rules and the accompanying explanation (annotation of amendments to the rules).  At present, it is mandatory to wear face masks:    public transport;  in taxis for passengers and the driver, unless another special barrier has been established, such as a wall;  bus stations, railway stations, ports and airports;  shop, pharmacy, postage, gas stations and other indoor outlets;  museum, library, exhibition halls, concert halls, cinemas and similar venues, in the absence of an event with personalised seating;  in churches in the absence of an event with personalised seats;  hospitals;  when providing an indoor service where a distance of 2 metres cannot be respected, there are no physically separating barriers and staying for more than 15 minutes.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/veselibas-ministrija-aicina-iespeju-robezas-stradajiet-attalinati

No evident policy change.    - Indoor events for up to 300 persons and outdoor events for up to 1,000 persons may be organised, subject to physical distancing, safety measures, and the rules set by the organiser   - A distance of at least one metre or a protective barrier between each group of fixed, personalised seats must be observed at events, following the rule that two visitors may be seated next to each other even if they are not from the same household; up to four visitors may be seated next to each other if they come from one household.   - When leaving the seat, visitors should keep a two-metre distance from each other if they are not from the same household.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

No evident policy change.    Using public transport:  - Face masks must be worn  - Hygiene measures must be observed  - Instructions available on public transport must be observed  - Upon arrival in Latvia from countries where the number of Covid-19 cases per 100,000 inhabitants exceeds 82,7 (list of countries is available on the SPKC website), public transport may only be used in order to get to the place of self-isolation, and a mouth and nose covering must be used  - Foreigners travelling to their home country must use a mouth and nose covering, if the required period of self-isolation since their arrival in Latvia has not yet finished  - Public transport must not be used by passengers who have tested positive for Covid-19 and by persons who have been in contact with a person infected with Covid-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

No evident policy change.  Only those who have tested positive for Covid-19 are forbidden to leave home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

No information has been found on internal movement restrictions in Latvia. No curfew is in place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

- The need for travel must be carefully assessed  - Self-isolation is not required after arriving from countries where the number of new Covid-19 infections does not exceed 61,9 new cases per 100000 inhabitants over the course of the last two weeks  - 10-day self-isolation must be observed after arriving in Latvia from countries with more than 61,9 new cases of Covid-19 infection per 100000 inhabitants over the course of the last two weeks  - 10-day self-isolation must be observed after arriving in Latvia from a country to which international passenger transport services are not being carried out    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures    https://web.archive.org/web/20201023061901/https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/valstu-saslimstibas-raditaji-ar-covid-19-0
No evident policy change.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201026230506/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No evident policy change.    Everyone has the opportunity to take the state-paid Covid-19 test even if there are no symptoms.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200929091233/https://covid19.gov.lv/biezak-uzdotie-jautajumi (archived 29 Sept 2020)    Any Latvian citizen with a suspicion of infection (visiting other countries, contact with persons who have been abroad, staying in public places where it was not possible to observe physical distance, frequent use of public transport, etc. conditions of increased risk of infection during the last 14 days) can initiate to carry out laboratory examinations paid for from the state budget on Covid-19 by applying for a laboratory examination by telephone (telephone 8303).  https://web.archive.org/web/20201014175129/https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/valsts-apmaksatas-covid-19-analizes-kam-tas-veic-un-ka-jarikojas (archived 14 Oct 2020)

From 24 October, private event venues may have a maximum of 10 people indoors and 100 people outdoors . If a private event is held in a public place, such as a restaurant, rented sauna, club, etc., then guests must be provided with fixed, personalized seating, 2 meters distance (except for persons from one household), as well as the event can take place until 24.00;    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026220648/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/nosaka-stingrakus-pulcesanas-un-citus-drosibas-pasakumus

- From 24 October mouth and nose covering should be worn in any public place.  - Mouth and nose covering should be used during indoor cultural events. The covering can not be removed if you are sitting in a fixed, personalized seat at a cultural event.   - A homemade mask should be made of at least three layers of suitable material (cotton, nylon, etc.) and have ties to secure it behind the ears or behind the head  - May not be used for children under 13 years of age and people who cannot use it for medical reasons, such as functional impairment    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

...the government decided that 7-12 Class students will study remotely for one week from October 26 to 30...    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026214546/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/uz-laiku-jaierobezo-cilveku-kustiba-arpus-katra-sociala-burbula

From 26 October to 15 November, work is suspended (places do not provide services) related to indoor entertainment for children (entertainment and amusement centers, children's playrooms, trampoline parks and babysitting rooms, including shopping centers);    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026220648/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/nosaka-stingrakus-pulcesanas-un-citus-drosibas-pasakumus

How can COVID-19 be analyzed?  From October 26, there is a new testing procedure. If Covid-19 is suspected, you should first contact your doctor. If the healthcare professional, after hearing the patient about their symptoms, decides that a test is needed, an e-mail will be issued. Then, when the person calls 8303, he or she will be queued for the test as soon as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026224302/https://covid19.gov.lv/biezak-uzdotie-jautajumi

According to the Decision No 31 from 24 September 2020 of the National Commission for Emergency in Public Health there are a series of relaxations to the limitations imposed before. These permissions are organization of exhibitions and fairs in open air with following of the sanitary measures and organization of cultural events (theatres, concerts) in inside/closed spaces with 50% of the capacity to be used only.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200929080034/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UN%20Moldova%20Covid-19%20Weekly%20Situation%20Report%2025%20September.pdf

Since September 28, the state of public health emergency has been lifted. As a result, The Extraordinary National Commission for Public Health are moving to a more de-centralized risk management / alert levels at a territorial level, this will be calculated and shared by the National Agency for Public Health every 14-days (see Annex 2 of the Decision). Territorial level public health commissions will then establish public health measures based upon the agreed alert level.  Overall, there is little that suggests that some stores still have to be closed; I would therefore code this as a 1.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201008021259/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UN%20Moldova%20COVID-19%20Response%20and%20Recovery%20Monlty%20Bulletin%20-%20September%202020.pdf

According to the IOM Global Mobility Restriction Overview Weekly update (published on 28 September), the Republic of Moldova issued restrictions barring entry of passengers from Austria, Belgium, Czechia, Jamaica, Monaco, Nepal, Netherlands, Oman, Portugal, Switzerland, United Arab Emirates, the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela and concurrently lifted restrictions to allow entry for passengers arriving from Ecuador, El Salvador, Eswatini, the Gambia, Guatemala, Kazakhstan, Kuwait, Luxembourg, Paraguay, Philippines, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and South Africa.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201004213811/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/DTM%20%28COVID-19%29%20Global%20Mobility%20Restriction%20Overview%20-%2028%20September%202020.pdf

According to the Social Economic Response and Recovery Plan (September version) published by UN Moldova office: n the field of social protection and basic services, the United Nations will support the Government to adopt, extend and scale-up services in several areas:     Targeted social assistance to vulnerable families affected by the decrease of income from remittances, and unemployment benefits for eligible returning migrants.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201004221925/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Moldova%20Covid-19_FINAL.pdf

As of October 12, the authorities instituted obligatory wearing of masks for students during all the time while in institutionâs premises, i.e. lectures, breaks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201019214704/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UN%20Moldova%20Covid-19%20Weekly%20Situation%20Report%2016%20October.pdf

As of 27 September 2020, the regional corona rules that had already been implemented since 20 September 2020 in the regions of Amsterdam-Amstelland, Rotterdam-Rijnmond, Haaglanden, Utrecht, Kennemerland and Hollands Midden, are extended to the following additional 8 regions:   Brabant-North; Brabant Southeast; Flevoland; Gelderland-South; Gooi and Vechtstreek; Groningen; Zaanstreek-Waterland; South Holland South. The key change is that in these areas, cafes, bars and restaurants are not permitted to have any new guests as of midnight, at which time the music has to be turned off and all guests have to leave by 01.00 a.m. In addition there is a new maximum of 50 persons at any event whether indoor or outdoor.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928144044/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/actueel/nieuws/2020/09/25/meer-regio%E2%80%99s-met-maatregelen-om-het-virus-in-te-dammen

As of 27 September 2020, the regional corona rules that had already been implemented since 20 September 2020 in the regions of Amsterdam-Amstelland, Rotterdam-Rijnmond, Haaglanden, Utrecht, Kennemerland and Hollands Midden, are extended to the following additional 8 regions:   Brabant-North; Brabant Southeast; Flevoland; Gelderland-South; Gooi and Vechtstreek; Groningen; Zaanstreek-Waterland; South Holland South. This applies, for example, to parties, drinks and outings for groups of this size. This applies both indoors and outdoors. There are a number of exceptions to this rule, such as demonstrations, religious gatherings, funerals, and dance and theater practices.  There is also a duty to report for meetings with more than 50 people. This applies, for example, to publicly accessible concerts in a park. An exception to this duty to report applies for, for example, occasions with a catering permit, religious gatherings, (supermarkets) markets, shops, libraries, cultural institutions and comparable locations where there is a flow of visitors.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928144044/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/actueel/nieuws/2020/09/25/meer-regio%E2%80%99s-met-maatregelen-om-het-virus-in-te-dammen

The rule of maximum 6 visitors in in a private gathering remains.   http://web.archive.org/web/20200928144044/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/actueel/nieuws/2020/09/25/meer-regio%E2%80%99s-met-maatregelen-om-het-virus-in-te-dammen

Government announced on 28 September 2020 continued support to help poor households with debt and poverty. The government is supporting the ability of the municipality to handle a much higher level of debt counselling for poor families.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928144349/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/actueel/nieuws/2020/09/28/extra-geld-voor-versterken-gemeentelijke-aanpak-schulden-en-armoede

During a national press conference, Prime Minister Mark Rutte and Minister of Health Hugo de Jonge announced new national measures that come into effect on Tuesday 29 September at 18.00 and will be in force for at least the next 3 weeks.  The new measures include:  - Working from home will remain the norm, unless this is absolutely impossible. If an infection occurs at a place of work, the workplace in question can be closed down for 14 days.  - Sports clubhouses will be closed.  - Indoor spaces with a continuous flow of visitors, such as historic buildings, libraries and museums must operate using reservations on the basis of time slots. This does not apply to retail stores and markets.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201008115110/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/09/28/additional-measures-to-combat-the-spread-of-coronavirus

During a national press conference, Prime Minister Mark Rutte and Minister of Health Hugo de Jonge announced new national measures that come into effect on Tuesday 29 September at 18.00 and will be in force for at least the next 3 weeks.  The new measures include:  - No more than 4 people can form a group in buildings other than someone's home (where the limit is 3).   - The number of people in one room is limited to 30 people. Outdoors the limit is 40 people. Exceptions are in place for certain events such as religious events or sports events. However, there are no exceptions mentioned for other types of public events and this in effect bans most public events both indoors and outdoors. Therefore, upgraded to 2G.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201008115110/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/09/28/additional-measures-to-combat-the-spread-of-coronavirus

During a national press conference, Prime Minister Mark Rutte and Minister of Health Hugo de Jonge announced new national measures that come into effect on Tuesday 29 September at 18.00 and will be in force for at least the next 3 weeks.  The new measures include:  - You can host no more than 3 guests in your home, garden or on your balcony. This is in addition to members of your own household and does not include children under the age of 13.  - In other buildings, no more than 4 people can form a group. This does not include children under the age of 13. This means that a single household or 4 people (maximum) â excluding children â can make a reservation at a cinema or restaurant.  - The number of people in one room is limited to 30 people. This includes children under 13 but excludes staff.    While there are a number of exceptions for private events (including funerals, and youth group meetings), there are restrictions qualifying for a 4 definitively in place. Hence, 4G maintained.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201008115110/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/09/28/additional-measures-to-combat-the-spread-of-coronavirus

During a national press conference, Prime Minister Mark Rutte and Minister of Health Hugo de Jonge announced new national measures that come into effect on Tuesday 29 September at 18.00 and will be in force for at least the next 3 weeks.  The new measures include:  - Working from home will remain the norm, unless this is absolutely impossible.  - The advice is to keep travel to a minimum.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201008115110/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/09/28/additional-measures-to-combat-the-spread-of-coronavirus

During a national press conference, Prime Minister Mark Rutte and Minister of Health Hugo de Jonge announced new national measures that come into effect on Tuesday 29 September at 18.00 and will be in force for at least the next 3 weeks.  The new measures include:  - Advice is to "keep travel to a minimum."    Hence, upgraded to 1G.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201008115110/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/09/28/additional-measures-to-combat-the-spread-of-coronavirus

Since 1 Oct 2020 the govt policy "NOW3" is in force: over the course of 3 times 3 months, until July 2021, people receive income support of 80%, 70% and 60% respectively.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201026183550/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-financiele-regelingen/overzicht-financiele-regelingen/now

In some situations, face masks are mandatory. They must be worn in some designated areas at Amsterdam Schiphol Airport. Face masks are also mandatory on public transport and private commercial transport, such as taxis or passenger vans.   In addition, from Oct 2nd everyone aged 13 or over is advised to wear a non-medical face mask in indoor public spaces such as: - shops, museums, town halls, stations, airports, covered car parks and petrol stations - restaurants, bars, cafÃ©s, theatres and concert halls - locations where contact-based professions are carried out (both customers and staff should wear a mask).  https://web.archive.org/web/20201008121756/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/09/28/additional-measures-to-combat-the-spread-of-coronavirus

All schools and universities open across the country, but for secondary schools and universities a govt-ordered 1.5 m distance must be maintained. In order to do so, schools and universities have moved part of their education online and have adapted their schedules so that fewer students have to be on the premises at the same time. Masks are recommended.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026154730/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-covid-19/ouders-scholieren-en-studenten-kinderopvang-en-onderwijs  https://web.archive.org/web/20201026154516/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-covid-19/openbaar-en-dagelijks-leven/mondkapjes/onderwijs

"You can travel freely in Norway if you can avoid spreading the infection. We all share the responsibility to follow the advice for infection control.    To travel in a way that will prevent you from spreading the infection means that you:    Do not travel if you are ill, nor to a holiday property.  Maintain good hand and cough hygiene.  Keep at least one metre distance to others not considered to be your closest contacts."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201005121649/https://www.helsenorge.no/koronavirus/reise/

"When arriving from a red area the following applies:    Keep wearing the face mask from your flight until you have reached home.  You need to be in travel quarantine for 10 days from the day of your arrival to Norway.  You should stay at home or in another suitable place of residence.  You should not go to work, school or kindergarten while in travel quarantine, but you can work from home.  You can travel by public transport from the place of arrival to the place where you will be in quarantine. If you are 12 years old or older you should wear a face mask.  You are not allowed to travel by public transport during your time in quarantine.  You can go for a walk, but only if you are able to keep a good distance to others.  You should make arrangements for others to help out with your grocery shopping or other necessary errands.  If you cannot make any such arrangements, you should visit the shop at times when only few others visit.  Wash your hands frequently and thoroughly.  Pay close attention to any symptoms developing.  Take a test for the coronavirus if you develop any symptoms, see the Coronavirus Self-Checker.  Violation of the quarantine duty is a criminal offence."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201005121649/https://www.helsenorge.no/koronavirus/reise/

"Situations where wearing a face mask is mandatory  It is mandatory to wear a face mask if you are over 12 years old when:    You will be in the travel quarantine and use public transport from the place of arrival to the place of quarantine  You leave Norway before the travel quarantine period is over and use public transport during the departure.  The municipal doctor makes a special assessment of whether you who are in quarantine infection can be allowed to use public transport to get to a suitable quarantine site."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201005122533/https://www.helsenorge.no/koronavirus/munnbind/

Working from home is recommended. Distancing measures in place in offices. Bars and restaurants remain open. https://web.archive.org/web/20201016180626/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/hjemmekontor-og-arbeidsplasser-covid-19

Norway distinguishes 'events in a public place with a responsible organizer'. Outdoors in a public place, it is allowed to hold events with up to 600 people present at the same time, as long as they are divided into groups of up to 200 people. The organizer must ensure that there is at least 2 meters distance between people in different groups at all times.  Indoors in a public place, it is allowed to hold events with up to 200 people present at the same time.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201016181644/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/arrangementer-gruppestorrelse-og-avstand

The national recommendation is that private gatherings can be held in groups of a maximum of 20 people, including yourself and those you live with.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201016181644/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/arrangementer-gruppestorrelse-og-avstand

Mandatory only in a very limited number of cases, all specific to quarantine:   - You travel by public transport from the place of arrival to the place where you will be in quarantine;   - You leave Norway prior to completing your quarantine duty period and travel by public transport to your place of departure;   - The municipal doctor specifically assesses your situation while you are in transmission quarantine to travel by public transport in order to reach a suitable place of residence.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201019164726/https://www.helsenorge.no/en/coronavirus/face-masks/

Latest update (15 Oct): Municipalities have the authority to close schools, but should avoid doing so as a general preventive measure. If a student or teacher becomes infected, their class must be quarantined, but the rest of the school has to carry on as normal. Schools may only be closed if there is a very high level of infection at the school, and only in consultation with national authorities. https://web.archive.org/web/20201016173548/https://www.udir.no/kvalitet-og-kompetanse/sikkerhet-og-beredskap/informasjon-om-koronaviruset/skole-korona/

Working from home is recommended. Distancing measures in place in offices.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201016180626/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/hjemmekontor-og-arbeidsplasser-covid-19

Public events with up to 600 people are allowed outside as long as a distance of 2 meters can be kept. The group of 600 also needs to be devided into groups of 200 or less. Inside public events with up to 200 people are allowed. From October 28th new restrictions will be implemented.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/arrangementer-gruppestorrelse-og-avstand#arrangementer-pa-offentlig-sted-kan-gjennomfores-med-inntil-600-personer-utendors-og-200-personer-innendors

https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/arrangementer-gruppestorrelse-og-avstand#private-sammenkomster-kan-gjennomfores-i-grupper-pa-maksimalt-20-personer  It is recommended that private events are limited to no more than 20 people including the people living in the house where the event takes place.   On October 26th it has been announced that from October 28th it is recommended that you as a private person do not invite more than 5 guest to your house.

Public transportation is not closed but it is recommended to wear masks when using public transportation.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/reiser-reiseliv-og-kollektivtransport#kollektivselskapene-bor-iverksette-ekstra-rengjoring-av-tog-t-banevogner-bater-busser-og-trikker

No restrictions on internal movement as long as the general guidance of keeping distance and not travelling if you feel sick is followed.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/reiser-reiseliv-og-kollektivtransport#fritidsreiser

It is possible to get a test when entering to Norway from a foreign country. If you enter Norway from a red country you need to quarantine yourself.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.helsedirektoratet.no/veiledere/koronavirus/reiser-reiseliv-og-kollektivtransport#ankommende-fra-utlandet-far-mulighet-til-a-teste-seg-gratis-ved-ankomst
Companies with employees can apply for compensation if they have seen a reduction in revenue as a consequence from Corona.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://kompensasjonsordning.no/

Norway has put many economic measures in place to mitigate economic effects of Covid-19 but none of theme seems to relate to debt and contract relief for private households.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/the-economy/economic-policy/economic-measures-in-norway-in-response-to-covid-19/id2703484/
Dedicated public webpage with advice and information related to the coronavirus.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.fhi.no/en/id/infectious-diseases/coronavirus/

The following should be tested (further information about each point can be found in the collapsible box below):     Everyone with acute respiratory tract infection or other symptoms of COVID-19  Everyone who has been exposed to infection to COVID-19, either as a close contact or after travel to countries or regions with high incidence during the last 10 days*  Other groups can be tested after assessment by a doctor. If a person without symptoms and who has not been exposed is tested, a positive test must be confirmed with a new test.  Anyone who suspects that they have COVID-19 should have the opportunity to be tested  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.fhi.no/en/op/novel-coronavirus-facts-advice/testing-and-follow-up/test-criteria-for-coronavirus/?term=&h=1

Follow-up of close contacts, isolation and quarantine are measures to prevent transmission of the virus that causes COVID-19. Isolation and quarantine should be carried out in the most appropriate place, preferably at home. When the measures are introduced elsewhere than at home, the same principles apply.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.fhi.no/en/op/novel-coronavirus-facts-advice/testing-and-follow-up/follow-up-close-contacts/?term=&h=1

In situations with increased risk of transmission and where it is difficult to keep distance, face masks can be recommended as part of the measures to reduce the risk of transmission. Follow the local recommendations for the areas you are staying in.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.fhi.no/en/op/novel-coronavirus-facts-advice/facts-and-general-advice/hand-hygiene-cough-etiquette-face-masks-cleaning-and-laundry/?term=&h=1

On October 26th the Norwegian Government has announced several new restrictions which will be implemented from October 28th and run until early December. As part of these restrictions Municipalities with local outbreaks are encouraged to take local measures with can include virtual learning.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.regjeringen.no/no/aktuelt/nye-nasjonale-innstramminger/id2776995/

The Council of Ministers approved measures stricter for three counties in the North region - Lousada, Felgueiras e PaÃ§os de Ferreira - that have registered a significant increase in the number of cases. The approved measures include: suspension of visits to care-homes, prohibition of events, duty to stay at home and mandatory teleworking. Rules take effect on Friday, October 23, at midnight.     Citizens should remain at home and refrain from circulating in public spaces and roads, except when the trips are authorized. Individuals are allowed to go out for grocery shopping, work (when teleworking is not possible), health reasons, to assist vulnerable people, attend school, physical activity in open spaces, cultural events, pet walk, among others.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201028111350/https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2020-10-22-Semi-confinamento-em-Lousada-Felgueiras-e-Pacos-de-Ferreira.-Eis-como-vai-ser--regra-a-regra-

Portugal's parliament on Friday passed a bill which imposed the mandatory use of a mask on the street and public spaces in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus.    The order was passed a day after authorities reported 3,270 new coronavirus cases, the highest single-day increase since the beginning of the pandemic. It will be in effect for at least 70 days.    The use of a mask is compulsory for all people "over ten years old to access, circulate or stay in public spaces and roads whenever the physical distance recommended by health authorities are impossible", according to the bill.    The obligation between "people from the same household, when they are not in the proximity of third parties" can be waived or by means of a "medical certificate" that the clinical condition or cognitive impairment does not allow the use of masks.    It is also not mandatory to wear a mask when "it is incompatible with the nature of the activities that people are carrying out."    Those who violate the order face fines of between 100 euros ($118) and 500 euros ($590). Other items such as visors will not be acceptable as substitutes.    The order will be reassessed following the expiry of the mandated period with a renewal a possibility."    These rules will be applied from Wednesday, October 28.     "The same rules will also be applied in Madeira and the Azores (...)"    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201028100351/https://newsaf.cgtn.com/news/2020-10-24/Portugal-s-Parliament-approves-mandatory-use-of-masks-in-outdoor-areas-UPMSI69oJy/index.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028100922/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2020-10-27-A-partir-de-quarta-feira-vai-ter-de-usar-mascara-na-rua

People entering Kosovo are subjected to a medical check (temperature measurement etc. but no COVID 19 test) by the local health authorities at the border.    Entrants from countries that  are classified as "High Risk Country" by the  ECDC (European Center for Disease Prevention and Control) must present a current Covid-19 negative test (sampling max. 72 hours before entry) upon entry within the framework of reciprocity. ravelers from these countries who are unable to submit a negative test must instead complete a 7-day quarantine. Direct transit from / to PriÅ¡tina Airport is permitted for all travellers without a test if the stay in Kosovo does not exceed 3 hours.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201017071616/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-situation-in-kosovo.html

In a meeting on August, 13 2020 the Government of the Republic of Kosovo, laid out a plan for the implementation of economic recovery, amounting to â¬365,000,000.00 (e.g. with exchange rate on August 13, USD 431,435,373.29). This recovery plan yields the following measures for income support:   MEASURE 3 â Increasing employment, in particular the employment of specific groups of workers with lower probability of getting employment, in the amount of sixty-seven million three hundred thousand Euros (â¬67,300,000.00);  MEASURE 3A â Subsidizing the salary for employees in businesses affected by the pandemic for March and April (170 Euros), in the amount of forty-seven million three hundred thousand Euros (â¬47,300,000.00);  MEASURE 3B â Subsidizing the salary for new employees hired by businesses based on a plan that identifies the sectors and categories of employees most in need, in the amount of five million Euros (â¬5,000,000.00);  MEASURE 3C â Providing professional support for businesses to operate in times of pandemic, such as work from home, online work, digital transformation, etc., in the amount of three million Euros (â¬3,000,000.00);  MEASURE 3D â Supporting the manufacturing and service businesses with equipment and machinery for process automation, in the amount of ten million Euros (â¬10,000,000.00); and  MEASURE 3E â Supporting the businesses in order to increase their productivity, in the amount of two million Euros (â¬2,000,000.00).  MEASURE 7 â Providing financial support for youth employment, support to civil society organizations, other informal groups, stimulation of cultural, artistic and sports activities and their revitalization, in the amount of five million Euros (â¬5,000,000.00);    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201018061725/https://kryeministri-ks.net/en/the-government-approves-the-plan-for-the-implementation-of-the-economic-recovery/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201018062518/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Kosovo.pdf

This recovery plan yields the following measures for debt/contract relief:   MEASURE 1 â Facilitating access to loans for private enterprises, to finance investment projects and business continuity, in the amount of one hundred million Euros (â¬100,000,000.00), with the following activities;  MEASURE 1A â Increasing the coverage of new loans through the Kosovo Credit Guarantee Fund, in the amount of sixty million Euros (â¬60,000,000.00);  MEASURE 1B â Covering the cost of the Kosovo Credit Guarantee Fund fee, in the amount of five million Euros (â¬5,000,000.00);  MEASURE 1C â Rescheduling the existing bank loans, where the cost of rescheduling is borne by the Government, in the amount of thirty million Euros (â¬30,000,000.00); and  MEASURE 1D â Subsidizing interest rates for certain sectors based on a strategic plan prepared by relevant stakeholders, in the amount of five million Euros (â¬5,000,000.00).  MEASURE 2F â Providing the opportunity to reschedule previous tax debts, including deductions for immediate debt repayment  MEASURE 4B â Subsidizing the interest rates on agricultural loans, in the amount of two million Euros (â¬2,000,000.00).  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201018061725/https://kryeministri-ks.net/en/the-government-approves-the-plan-for-the-implementation-of-the-economic-recovery/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201018062518/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Kosovo.pdf

On the 6th October, Romanian authorities announced they will close theatres, cinemas and indoor restaurants in the capital Bucharest and several other cities from Wednesday 7th October to try to stem an increase in coronavirus infections. The restrictions will remain in place until the number of infections in the affected areas drops to 1.5 per 1,000 people over 14 days.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201008225452if_/https://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKL8N2GX5JZ

"On 5 October 2020, the Romanian Government issued an updated list of countries for which COVID-19 travel restrictions are in place.    From midnight on 7 October 2020, travellers arriving into Romania from the UK must quarantine for 14 days on arrival. If however, after 8 days of quarantine, you present no specific COVID-19 symptoms and take a COVID-19 test which returns a negative result, you may leave quarantine after 10 days.      Travellers planning to stay in Romania for 3 days or less are exempt from quarantine, as long as they provide evidence of a negative COVID-19 test, taken within 48 hours before entering the country."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201019133449/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/romania/entry-requirements    "Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? No, unless they meet one of the exceptions for entry listed in the Government Decision of August 16.  U.S. citizens are not permitted to enter Romania unless they meet one of the specified exceptions.  U.S. citizens wishing to know if they meet an exception for entry may consult the Ministry of Foreign Affairsâ website here or the Ministry of Interiorâs website here (Romanian language only). They are also advised to contact the Romanian Embassy in their country of origin or the Romanian Border Police prior to departure.  The Government of Romania also implemented non-European Economic Area (EEA) travel requirements reflecting the Council of the European Unionâs (EUâs) June 30th recommendations, which prohibit non-essential EU travel for U.S. residents.  Travelers may consult the European Commissionâs webpage called âRe-open EUâ for more information regarding travel restrictions throughout Europe."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201019133540/https://ro.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Ministry of Education and Research announced on 22nd of October that 2401 education units are listed to work in red scenario (Scenario 3), involving the participation only in online activities. 4891 education units are listed in Scenario 2, meaning partial return (by rotation) in compliance with all rules of protection and 10364 in Scenario 1 (daily participation in compliance with all health protection rules).  According to the Order of the Minister of Education and Research and the Minister of Health 5487/1494/01.09.2020, one of the three operating scenarios is the cumulative incidence rate, respectively the total number of new cases in the last 14 days compared to 1000 inhabitants.  Links: https://archive.fo/EUjeg and https://archive.fo/qi24y

Starting with 20th of October, the Bucharest City Committee for Emergency Situations announced that all activities carried out indoors in restaurants, coffee-shops, cinemas, theaters and gambling halls will be closed for at least 14 days, as disease rate of the city was over 3.  Also, the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection recommended on 10th of March measures to make labor relations more flexible (establishing individualized work programs, temporary modification of the workplace at the employeeâs domicile, carrying out the activity through telework).  Link: https://archive.fo/mfaPX  and https://archive.fo/YIB63

According to the Governmentâs order 856/14.10.2020, public meetings, rallies, and demonstrations with no more than 100 participants are allowed in compliance with all rules of protection.  Link: https://archive.fo/NUj4k
During the alert state, the protective mask shall be worn in any enclosed public space, public transport and at work, according to Order MS-MAI 874/81/2020.  Link: https://archive.fo/cUlEp
Link: https://archive.fo/cUlEp
There are no traffic restrictions between localities except for quarantined areas.  Link: https://archive.fo/9KkOQ

Conditions of ban arrivals from different regions are defined in the Government Decision since 16th of August 2020. Also, there are screening procedures implemented at the âHenri Coandaâ International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions).    Link: https://archive.fo/lx6tV and https://archive.fo/9KkOQ

The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Also, GEO 30/2020 refers to the measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.      Link: https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://archive.fo/FtT0q.

Ministry of Health published âRecommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)â and âRecommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemicâ.   Links: https://archive.fo/cUlEp and https://archive.fo/klswT

According to the Ministry of Health, the units that are accredited by the Ministry of Health to perform the diagnosis by RT-PCR  have the obligation to provide priority diagnosis for patients in health facilities, suspects in epidemiological investigations, and people at risk, according to the methodology of the National Institute of Public Health â National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases.   Link: https://archive.fo/6K5UM

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi

The Minister of Health, Nelu Tataru, announced on 22nd of May the obligation to wear a protective mask, epidemiological triage and mandatory hand disinfection to prevent contamination with SARS CoV-2 virus during the alert state. According to the Government Decision 394/2020, from 15th of October 2020, the alert status will be extended by 30 days. Moreover, starting with 20th of October, the Bucharest City Committee for Emergency Situations announced that the protective mask must be worn both indoors and outdoors, as disease rate was over 3.    Link: https://archive.fo/gZHhT,  https://archive.fo/Edc8p and https://archive.fo/mfaPX

The federal government had announced a three-stage reopening plan giving regional governors discretion on the pace. The second stage will allow schools to open. As of early October 7, 44 regions were in the second stage. See https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 [accessed 12th October 2020, web archive unavailable]

The federal government had announced a three-stage reopening plan giving regional governors discretion on the pace. During the first stage of reopening, people can walk and exercise outdoors, and small shops and service-sector establishments will reopen. The second stage will allow schools and larger shops and service-sector businesses to open. In the third stage, parks, hotels, restaurants, and all shops will reopen. Criteria for lifting restrictions in specific regions include infection rates, the availability of hospital beds, and testing capacity.    As of early October 7, 5 regions were in the first stage, 44 in the second and 37 in the third. See https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 [accessed 12th October 2020, web archive unavailable]

The Russian Government is allowing regular international flights to resume, but only to destinations that have met benchmarks for containing the spread of COVID-19. Limited numbers of flights are available to other locations.  Air travel remains erratic and subject to cancellations.  Aeroflot continues to have weekly flights from Moscow to New York.  In addition, flights from Moscow to Istanbul on Turkish Airways and to London on British Airways have restarted.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201017035018/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"The Slovak government has announced that it will declare a state of emergency on Thursday, October 1, due to an increase in cases of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). The emergency will be in place for at least 45 days and will allow the government more powers to implement stricter measures to combat the spread of COVID-19. Despite this, the government has not yet announced a return to the full lockdown measures previously seen in the country. The country's previous state of emergency was declared on March 16 and lasted until June 14.    Slovak authorities announced on September 28 enhanced restrictive measures to combat COVID-19 infections in the country. The new measures, set to go into effect from Thursday, include prohibiting many outdoor gatherings including all family, sports, cultural, and religious events. Exceptions to the mandate include weddings, baptisms, and funerals, as well as for players of sporting competitions providing that all involved test negative for COVID-19 in the preceding 12 hours. Additionally, all bars, restaurants, and clubs are required to close at 22:00 (local time).    As of October 1, authorities have confirmed 10,141 cases of COVID-19 in the country and 48 associated fatalities. Further international spread of the virus is to be expected over the near term." https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/385066/slovakia-government-to-declare-state-of-emergency-october-1-update-11

"All retail businesses and service providers are ordered to ensure:    the number of customers in an establishment in any one moment does not exceed one customer per 10 sq. m of the establishmentâs floor area or  keeping a distance between individual customers of at least 2 m (alternatively, the above condition does not apply to food establishments providing the operator ensures that dining tables are spaced at least 2 m apart).    However, operators are required to make sure the following:     entry and stay in premises (within interior spaces) to be allowed only with covered upper airways (face mask, shawl, scarf); this obligation does not apply to time necessary for consumption of beverages and food in public food facilities,  upon entry to premises apply disinfectionto hands of provide disposable gloves,  keeping a distance of at least 2 m between customers standing in a queue (this does not apply to persons living in a common household),  all entrances to premises to have visibly displayed notification on the obligation to comply with the above hygienic measures,  perform frequent ventilation of premises and perform regular disinfection of touch surfaces, such as door handles, shopping trolleys and baskets, any equipment in use, tools and instruments, use virucidal disinfectant for disinfection,  food stores, public food facilities, including fast food stands and any other street vending of foodstuffs, meals and beverages mustplace emphasis on securing regular cleaning and disinfection that must be done within the daily sanitation operation and within the adopted and introduced principles of correct hygienic practice according to Regulation No 852/2004 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the hygiene of foodstuffs."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201013192040/https://korona.gov.sk/en/platne-hygienicke-opatrenia-okt-en/

"A ban is imposed on organising mass sporting, cultural, entertainment, social events, or events of other nature with more than 50 attendees at one time. If the number of persons at the above events performing on the organiserâs behalf exceeds 50 persons (performers, athletes, sports event organisers, etc.), a mass event will be held without live audience.    In parallel, it is prohibited to:    organise mass, cultural, entertainment, social gatherings or gatherings of other nature (discotheques, dance events, etc.) in catering establishments (restaurants, bars, nightclubs, bars, etc.) and in accommodation facilities. The restriction does not apply to the regular provision of catering services in food establishments,  organise large social gatherings (wedding  receptions, celebrations, dance balls, funeral feasts, green ribbon parties of students, etc.)."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201013192040/https://korona.gov.sk/en/platne-hygienicke-opatrenia-okt-en/

"How can I travel between Slovakia and countries not on the "low-risk countries" list?  Everybody who enters Slovakia and visited countries not on the list of low-risk countries during the past 14 days has to register at korona.gov.sk. The form requires you to fill in a phone number, a place of isolation, and the name of your attending physician. When entering the country, you should be able to show police officers a confirmation about registration on the website.    There are certain differences for people coming from EU and non-EU countries not on the green list.    Everybody who enters Slovakia and visited EU member states not on the list of low-risk countries during the past 14 days needs to enter home isolation.    Home isolation ends after 10 days or after you have received a negative COVID-19 test usually taken on the 5th day after arrival (children younger than three years of age are an exception)."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201013193452/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22427760/coronavirus-in-slovakia-how-to-travel-borders-bus-train-air-transport.html?ref=tab

"Wearing a veil in public outdoors is mandatory if it is not possible to keep a distance of at least 2 meters from strangers.    The obligation to wear a veil everywhere in interiors (even in public transport) outside their place of residence for all persons in the territory of the Slovak Republic continues to apply. This obligation also applies when wearing an exhalation respirator, which must also be covered with a drape.    Instead of a drape, you can use a scarf or other means to prevent the droplets from spreading to the surroundings."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201013194216/https://korona.gov.sk/povinnost-nosit-rusko-okt/

"It will be strongly recommended to wear drapes in kindergartens, for the first and second grade of primary schools is mandatory. Exceptions to wearing veils will apply to deaf, autistic children or children with mental disorders.    High schools will switch to distance education. "Today we will issue a decision suspending teaching in secondary schools. Secondary schools are moving to distance education from tomorrow until further notice," the Minister of Education clarified.     The lower grades of eight-year grammar schools, which correspond to the grades in primary school, will operate in the normal regime with the mandatory wearing of veils.   He also encouraged students not to go to boarding schools. Teachers, in turn, to prepare students for distance learning and prepare schedules for a few weeks in advance."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201013191112/https://www.minedu.sk/minister-skolstva-oznamil-nove-opatrenia-v-skolach-platne-od-12-oktobra/

At today's correspondence session, the Government adopted a proposal for the Intervention Measures Act to mitigate and eliminate the consequences of COVID-19 or the so-called fifth anti-crown package.    The bill for employees extends the measure of 100 percent compensation of salary in the case of ordered quarantine due to contact with an infected person at work. From 1 September 2020 onwards, it will be possible to claim 80% compensation in the event of absence from work due to child protection due to force majeure (child quarantine).  For employers, the possibility of reimbursing compensation for wages paid for absence from work due to the ordered quarantine is extended. In addition, they are relieved of the possibility of reimbursement of salary compensation due to absence from work due to childcare (force majeure).  The press release issued by the government late last night indicated no major changes to the previous version of the bill, which entails measures for healthcare, labour, social security, economy, education, justice, criminal sanctions, agriculture and infrastructure. Previous policies still in place with the fifth package, hence 1A maintained. https://web.archive.org/web/20201001180911/https://www.gov.si/novice/2020-09-29-98-dopisna-seja-vlade-republike-slovenije/ https://web.archive.org/web/20201001185704/https://www.total-slovenia-news.com/news/7057-morning-headlines-for-slovenia

The EU, including Slovenia, has enacted a general ban on travel from the United States. U.S. citizens with residency in an EU country may enter Slovenia.  For other U.S. citizens who first spend two weeks in a third country, Slovenia may grant entry, depending on the country of origin.  (See Quarantine section below.)  In addition, immediate family members (but not fiancÃ©s) of Slovenian citizens coming from the United States are permitted with a transit letter from the Slovenian embassy in Washington, DC.  Travelers from the United States who are permitted entry may be subject to quarantine and Covid-19 testing. "As of Monday [= 19 Oct], lessons in primary schools will be implemented remotely from the fifth grade onward. The same applies to secondary schools, while the recommendation to implement activities remotely, if possible, already applies to higher education colleges and universities," highlighted the Prime Minister. He continued to say that the regularly scheduled autumn holidays follow on from next week, at which time it will be assessed whether remote learning would be extended, cancelled or further tightened, dependent on the situation at the time. "We believe that a 14-day break will allow for the situation to stabilise or for the trends to be at least partially reversed," said the Prime Minister.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201022183448/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2020-10-14-prime-minister-janez-jansa-has-presented-the-latest-measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-coronavirus-infection/

https://web.archive.org/web/20201027225052/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/    Why are schools and pre-schools not closed in Sweden?  Listen   The Public Health Agency does not currently consider it necessary to close all schools in Sweden. There are no scientific evidence indicating that such an intervention would have any significant impact on the pandemic, nor has any major transmission of COVID-19 in schools been reported.    Closing schools and pre-schools would have a negative impact on society. For example, essential workers to the public (e.g. healthcare staff) would need to stay at home with their children. It could also put vulnerable groups, such as grandparents, at risk if they help out with childcare.    School is also a place of safety and stability for many children. Before closing a school, there must be plans made for alternative places where the children should go instead. However, it is of utmost importance that staff and children who have any symptoms of illness stay at home.    The Swedish Parliament has passed a bill (2020:148) allowing temporary closure of schools and pre-schools due to extraordinary events, making it possible for the Government or the head of a school to close schools under particular circumstances. There is also a regulation (2020:115) regarding the provision of education for pupils during a school closure.

https://web.archive.org/web/20200823055200/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/employees-employers-and-businesses    Employers who have the option of letting employees work from home may consider recommending that. Working remotely can reduce the spread of infection and relieve the load on the health service.

https://web.archive.org/web/20201020095315/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    Ban on public gatherings of 50 people or more  Public gatherings and events may have a maximum of 50 participants. The police can cancel or disband a public gathering or event with more than 50 participants. Anyone who organises an event that violates the ban can face a fine or prison sentence of a maximum of six months.    Public gatherings include the following:  -gatherings that constitute demonstrations or which are otherwise held for discussion, expression of opinion or providing    information on public or private matters;  -lectures and speeches held for the purposes of teaching or for public or civic education;  -gatherings for religious practice;  -theatrical and cinema performances, concerts and other gatherings for the performance of artistic work, and   other gatherings at which freedom of assembly is exercised.    Public events include the following:  -competitions and exhibitions in sports and aviation;  -dance performances;  -fairground amusements and parades;  -markets and fairs, and  -other events not regarded as public gatherings or circus performances.    Schools, public transport, private events and visits to shops are excluded.    Restaurants and cafes are exempt from the ban  The Swedish Government has decided that restaurants and cafes shall be exempt from the 50-person limit. The change applies from 8 October 2020. Read more about the exemption on the Swedish Police Authority website (in Swedish).

Preventive sickness benefit for risk groups  The Government's ordinance means a right to compensation of up to SEK 804 per day for people who belong to risk groups and for family members of people who belong to risk groups. The benefits are paid for the period when the person refrains from work to avoid being infected by the COVID-19 disease or infecting family members with that disease. The ordinance entered into force on 1 July 2020.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200718064633/https://www.government.se/articles/2020/07/about-the-covid-19-virus-for-older-people-people-with-health-conditions-and-health-and-social-care-staff-24-june/

Q: What is your advice regarding face masks?  A: We do not currently recommend face masks in public settings since the scientific evidence around the effectiveness of face masks in combatting the spread of infection is unclear. However, there may be situations where face masks can be useful despite the uncertain state of knowledge about the effects.  Face masks must always be seen as complementary to other recommendations: stay at home when you have symptoms, wash your hands regularly and keep at a distance from others.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201003070614/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/

Tajikistan, Uzbekistan to discuss reopening of borders, resumption of flights.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200928123707/https://akipress.com/news:648710:Tajikistan,_Uzbekistan_to_discuss_reopening_of_borders,_resumption_of_flights/

On March 20, the Tajikistan government closed international borders amid fear of a COVID-19 outbreak. Currently, the government has not opened borders with all countries. For example, Tajikistan is planning to open flights with Russia and Uzbekistan in the near future. Link: https://archive.vn/ILJRZ
On September 29, it was reported that more than 50 residents of Khujand city were fined for not wearing face masks in public areas.  The link: https://archive.vn/DDXOn
Mosques are still closed in Tajikistan. The Ministry of Healthcare stated that the government has not decided to open mosques yet.  Link: https://archive.vn/D3KK7
Dushanbe resumes flights with Istanbul (Turkey) and Urumqi (China) in October.  Link: https://archive.vn/oSsnW

On October 10, it was reported that the local administration of Khujand city temporarily closed some restaurants and cafes for not following hygiene and social distancing rules.  The link: https://archive.vn/qeb0Q

On October 11, the presidential elections were held in Tajikistan. The government developed instructions for voters to follow strict hygiene and social distancing rules. About 4,2 million people have voted in the elections.  Links: https://archive.vn/2K8uj https://archive.vn/vDagh
Dushanbe resumes flights with Krasnoyarsk (Russia).  Link: https://archive.vn/0BHoj

On October 16, it was reported that teachers from Russia arrived in Tajikistan. Russian teachers have been allocated among different regions of Tajikistan to teach Tajik school learners. Schools in Tajikistan are open since August.   Link: https://archive.vn/kviog
Public places and services in Tajikistan were allowed to re-open in mid-June. Local regulations, including wearing of face masks, should be observed at all times.  Link: https://archive.vn/FNnWg
Religious gatherings and other large events are prohibited.  Link: https://archive.vn/lgEfQ

Gatherings are allowed for a maximum of 100 people. However, Tajiks are not fully complying with this rule. For example, residents of Khujand city are organizing weddings by not following government recommendations and inviting more than 100 people to weddings. Mayor of Khujand city ordered to strictly monitor the wedding events on whether the residents are complying with all government recommendations/rules or not.  Link: https://archive.vn/27XFa
Is public transportation operating? Yes  Masks are required on public transportation.  Link: https://archive.vn/lgEfQ
Is a curfew in place? No  Link: https://archive.vn/lgEfQ
Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Link: https://archive.vn/lgEfQ

Are commercial flights operating? Yes  FlyDubai and Somon Air operate flights between Dushanbe and Dubai. Turkish Airlines operates flights between Dushanbe and Istanbul once per week. However, the Dushanbe International Airport is currently closed to most commercial flights.  The airport has not announced when operations will resume.  Link: https://archive.vn/lgEfQ

There are no updates on whether the government is still providing income support to residents who lost their jobs during the COVID-19. However, on October 18, it was reported that the government has not provided the promised additional salary to health workers on a regular basis. The doctor said that he received an additional salary only once. Moreover, it should be mentioned that the Government of Tajikistan, with support from the World Bank, has been providing emergency cash transfers to low-income families with young children: More than 25,000 of the countryâs poorest families with children under three have received a one-time payment of 500 TJS (around US$50) to help cover essentials such as food and medication during the crisis. Links: https://archive.vn/wjMSS https://archive.vn/rSbeQ
Tariff increases on electricity, water, and communal services have been postponed until end of 2020.   Link: https://archive.vn/tPm0s
There is a website https://covid.tj./ that informs citizens about COVID-19 infections in the country on a daily basis.   Link: https://archive.vn/EWLpd

There are no new updates. On September 22, the Tajikistan government announced that there is no mass testing policy across the country. Accordingly, people with COVID-19 symptoms and close contacts will be tested for COVID-19.   Link: https://archive.vn/URZIJ
No new updates. On September 22, it was reported that contact people are tested for a COVID-19.   Link: https://archive.vn/URZIJ
The Tajik government has mandated the use of masks in public.  Failure to wear a protective face mask in public may result in a fine.  Link: https://archive.vn/lgEfQ
On October 18, it was reported that citizens of Tajikistan are not fully complying with the mask regime.  Link: https://archive.vn/hafYN

All arrivals into Turkey will be subject to a medical evaluation for symptoms of coronavirus, including temperature checks. Any passengers showing symptoms including high fever, coughing or respiratory difficulties will be will be required to undergo a PCR test (a swab test â see here for details) for coronavirus.    In the event that a test returns a positive result, you will be provided with medical treatment at a facility determined by the Ministry of Health or, if preferred, at a private medical facility in Turkey. Those who do not abide by this rule may be issued with a fine of 900 TL (approximately Â£106)

This does not apply to foreign tourists. This can be done through the e-Devlet system, the âHayat Eve Sigarâ smartphone application and by SMS.    IF YOU HAVE A TURKISH RESIDENT ID: Send a text message to phone number 2023 that includes (a) the letters âHESâ, (b) your Turkish kimlik number (c) your year of birth, and (d) the number of days you will be traveling, plus 7 days. Put a single space between each item.    IF YOU HAVE TURKISH CITIZENSHIP: Send a text message to phone number 2023 that includes (a) the letters âHESâ, (b) your Turkish kimlik number (c) the last four digits of the series number of your ID, and (d) surname, the number of days you will be traveling, plus 7 days should be used. On 29 September, the Ukraine opened its borders for international travel. Countries are divided into green and red categories. "Green" countries do not have to take any measures, whilst "red" countries can choose from the following three options: 1. Observation in specialized isolators;    2. 14 days self-isolation at the place of residence for persons who have agreed to undergo it using the "Diy Vdoma" mobile app;    3. Pass the COVID-19 test using the PCR method after crossing the state border.    Link: https://archive.fo/XBDLg
